Our trade with Sierra Leone is mainly dependent upon the caravan traffic between the British port of Freetown and the upper portion of the Niger.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.732, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sierra Leone is not a colony about which we can boast very much. It is about 102 years old, thus considerably younger than the Gambia, which almost ranks with Newfoundland as being one of the very first British possessions abroad. Sierra Leone, however, has not much to show for its century of British rule. Its frontier along the coast now extends for about 180 miles, and reaches inland for an average distance of 100 miles, although we only exercise effective rule over a limited portion of this area. The harbour of Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, is the only good harbour on the West Coast between the ports of the Cape Verde Islands and the Island of Fernando Po, off the Niger Delta. As such, and as one of our fortified coaling stations, the importance of the retention and development of this colony cannot be lost sight of. The native races of Sierra Leone belong principally to the Timani and Bulom and Mandingo families. The town is beautifully situated at the corner of a peninsula and at the base of fantastic wooded mountains. Much else of the colony is flat and even swampy; and this little mountainous peninsula jutting out into the sea probably represents the highest ground within the limits of this possession. At the back of Sierra Leone we practically have the Upper Niger, the sources of which are not many days' journey from the Sierra Leone boundary. Here at present the great Mahommedan Chief Samadu is the actual ruler, and has created one of those African empires which are easily reared by successful robbers with extravagant bloodshed and widespread depredation. Samadu has several times fought the French on the Senegambian frontier, but of late he is said to have concluded peace with them. The productions of Sierra Leone are those of true Western Africa, and the colony is rich and well-favoured in vegetable wealth. It exports palm oil, palm kernels, rubber, gum, camwood, besides skins and benniseed and ground nuts.

Liberia is British in language, and to a great extent in such culture as it possesses, although it enjoys an independent Government. But its native inhabitants, the Kru-boys, are under the delusion that they are British subjects "of a sort," and do not admit any political connexion with the Americanised negroes who claim to govern them. On the east of Liberia, between the frontier and the west boundary of the French Gold Coast, is the Ivory Coast, about 100 miles in extent, and one of the last portions of the African coast, which remains unclaimed, unprotected, and unannexed by any European Power. Such trade as is done with it is purely British, and is chiefly with the town of Bristol. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will be considered presently whether larger reductions cannot be effected in the cost for military establishments without endangering the security of the settlements, and with increased efficiency to their administration.

Admitting that there may have been errors in the administration of these settlements, that their finances may not have been always carefully managed, and that differences or collisions with the natives have occurred which greater forethought or judgment might perhaps have in some instances prevented, it cannot be denied that, from their circumstances and position, they are exposed to risks and embarrassments from which most other colonies are free, and that whenever settlements are brought into contact with warlike and lawless savages, such complications as have occurred on the West Coast are by no means unfrequent, and are generally productive of financial and other difficulties.

The possibility of introducing improvements into their administration will, however, presently form a subject of consideration.

The suggestion that the benefits accruing from the settlements would be as readily obtained were they abolished, or, at least, made trading posts with a consul, is supposed to be supported by the fact that the oil rivers, as the district is termed in which the Benin, Nun, Calabar, and Bonny Rivers are situated, have a trade in palm oil exceeding that of the settlements, and yet that it is sustained without any aid or interference from Government.

This statement is perfectly correct, except as regards the non-interference of the Government, the Commodore being compelled at times to exercise all the authority which the power of the squadron gives him to maintain order in these rivers, which are said to be occasionally the scene of great irregularities.

It must, however, be borne in mind that the district in question is most prolific in palm-oil trees, and that ready access is obtainable to it through its numerous rivers; thus favourably situated, Europeans had every opportunity of making the natives aware of the value of the produce that lay around them, and of inducing them to turn their attention to its collection, whilst the facilities which were afforded the trade were such as are not to be found in any other part of Africa.

Urged by these considerations, the chiefs were soon led to see that it was more advantageous to employ their slaves in the manufacture of palm oil than to sell them; and it is easy to understand how, under these circumstances, no Government aid should have been required to create the large trade that now exists, and by its agency has abolished the former traffic in slaves.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.7, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Two important reports have just been issued dealing with two of our somewhat neglected colonies on the West Coast of Africa, colonies which, now that international competition is so intense, should be kept hold of with a firm hand. When the whole of the Niger region is confederated under Imperial rule the region stretching west and north-west from the mouths of the great river may become extremely valuable to British commerce. As it is, a work of great importance has just been concluded in the interests of England. The encroachments of the French on our West African sphere are well known to those who have been watching events in that part of the world. Their evident aim was so to surround our four little colonies as to shut them out completely from the interior, and ruin them so far as their trade goes. Fortunately, H.E. Alfred Moloney, Governor of Lagos, saw clearly what the policy of the French was, and from his knowledge of the country and people was able to take steps to preserve for Lagos a free route to the interior and the commerce of the native markets, and to bring a large and valuable country within the sphere of British influence. Practically the whole of the fine Yoruba country has been attached and free access obtained to and beyond the Kong Mountains, and to the sphere of the Royal Niger Company. Governor Moloney deserves to be congratulated on having accomplished this delicate task.

His report on Lagos for 1888, just issued, is voluminous and abounds in information as to the condition of the colony. He begins with a useful comparative statement of the tariffs of the Gambia, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Gold Coast, Lagos, the intervening French and German possessions, and the Royal Niger Territory. Lagos was acquired by treaty in 1861, and the report embodies figures showing its growth since. The revenue for 1887 came to £51,347, while the expenditure reached...
163

£78,610. The excess represented exceptional outlay from the credit funds of the colony on increased and necessary accommodation. The credit of the colony, represented by its investments, &c., amounted, on the close of the year, to £38,059.

The colony is self-dependent as regards its defence. Its force consists of Houssas (Mohammedans) and Yorubas, numbers some 400, and costs nearly £12,000 per annum.

It is satisfactory to notice the addition to the fixed establishments of provision for a botanical station as a distributing centre for economic plants of commercial value. The history of this important measure and the progress attained has appeared in the monthly bulletin of the Royal Gardens, Kew, from which it would appear we are indebted for so important a work to Governor Moloney, who has himself published a useful handbook on West African Forestry.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-11-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_11_1889#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.712, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH ADMINISTRATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'West Africa is one of the richest mineral regions on the planet, and England has been given an entrance to it for the purpose of spreading a civilisation and Christianity that will not do harm to the cause of the Gospel or bring disgrace on morality. The Mohammedan traders on the west coast of Sierra Leone, when asked where they get their precious metals and fine work, turn round and point to the north-east—Segoo, Bambara. Why have we not been in Bambara years ago? A light railway should have been run up to the north-east. The French are outstripping us along the line, and they deserve to; for St. Louis alone is an example of their superiority to us as colonisers. They are tapping all that rich region while we remain inert.

West Africa has, from interested motives, been represented as unhealthy for Europeans. This illusion is being rapidly dispelled by disinterested travellers. The Englishman, through unhealthy habits, may dig his own grave even in England, as so many thousands do annually. Besides, were London as innocent of sanitary arrangements as Freetown, it would soon become the white man's grave in grim reality. A man unaddicted to drink and gluttony may live, and does live, an enjoyable life in West Africa; he enjoys it so much that, like Emin Pasha, he refuses to be rescued. Officers and others have told me they preferred being out there for a time, not only because they liked the life, but because "dear old Cox" has been able to transfer the balance of their account from the debit to the credit side.

West Africa is the coming country; it teems with wealth; it is within easy distance of this country, and can be brought within six days of the London market if necessary. All that we require to do is to get rid of the drink, open out the country as honest people, and make room for our surplus population, from the nobleman's son down to the humblest artisan and labourer. There is fibre there for our manufacturers of Lancashire and Yorkshire; there is gold, silver, copper, coal, precious stones, ivory, india-rubber, nitrate, indigo, antimony, guano, palm oil, kola, ebony, mahogany, gum-copal, potash, ginger, gum, iron, farinaceous foods, dye woods, tanning material, spices, coffee, tobacco, cocoa, cotton, and other produce. Some of these vegetable products grow wild. Horses, camels, and sheep, can be bred in the north-east. The list of articles to be found on the coast reads like the inventory of a Liverpool warehouse. The wealth of West Africa is simply boundless, illimitable. It confirms Lord Palmerston's prediction of it in 1860, when he said that it "would be a source of wealth, not to Europe only, but to the world, to such an extent that imagination itself could hardly follow it."', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.731, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BANK FOR BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "extensive. Every year the missionary schools discharge a number of educated men and women who almost invariably embark in trade. Most of them have some small capital, which they use to trade with the interior natives, and the produce they thus obtain they either ship on consignment to England, to obtain the proceeds in British and other goods and silver coin, or sell it to the large British and foreign mercantile houses on the Coast, receiving goods from them in exchange for a renewal of operations with the producers in the interior. These native traders almost universally prefer to remit their produce to Europe for sale; but in this they labour under the great disadvantage of having their capital locked up until they obtain from Europe the proceeds of the sales, in goods or money. They estimate their loss through such delays at something like 25 per cent., and there can be no doubt that the facilities a bank might safely afford would be productive of great gain, both to the traders and the bank; while, if the limits of our article would permit, we could point out how the European mercantile establishments may also be largely benefited thereby. To every one acquainted with the business of the West Coast, and the mode in which it is conducted, it is patent that the establishment of a well-conducted bank, with adequate capital, will lead to a greatly increased production on the West Coast—in a few years, it may be, to 100 per cent. increase. A bank, moreover, that is capable of offering ample guarantees for the safety of moneys deposited with it, cannot fail of being highly useful to the public service as bankers to the several Administrations, receiving from the Colonial Treasurers the proceeds of the Customs' duties and other sources of revenue, and holding them at the disposal of the Government in the shape most convenient to the latter. Such a bank will link West Africa, now isolated, with the great financial system of the civilized world, giving her a recognized position therein—a fact of enormous importance for the British West African Settlements, when we consider that almost everything that can be accomplished by capital has yet to be effected there. All the aids and appliances of civilization for facilitating communications between the Coast and the interior, for economizing labour, for the transport of goods and produce, and for the development of the abounding natural and mineral resources, have yet to be introduced; and a well-established bank, giving large dividends to its shareholders, will show European capital the way to further profitable investment in those too long neglected countries. We have always steadfastly maintained that ere many years the West Africa Settlements will take rank among the most valuable colonial possessions of Great Britain, and every fresh step towards the realization of this prediction is to us a source of real delight. The bank is such a step, and we shall welcome it with all our heart. We can assure it, too, a welcome all along the West Coast, to which it cannot fail to prove a benefactor. Our only regret at this moment is, that it will not be brought before the public in time for us to advertise it more fully in this number of our journal. But we have sounded the note of preparation, and our readers may confidently await its beneficial advent.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1881#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.697, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'British Influence on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following letter has been addressed recently to Earl Granville by the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, on behalf of the African Trade Section of that Chamber:—

"My Lord,—I am requested by the Council of this Chamber to ask that your serious consideration may be given to the following facts, many of which are doubtless well known to you, but which have a special significance owing to the position of matters in West Africa at the present time. The British protectorate, as you are aware, is extended over a large portion of the Coast of Africa, which stretches from the settlement of Sierra Leone to the district of the Niger. Upon this coast, excluding the State of Liberia and the neighbourhood of Whydah, the port of Dahomey, there are three French settlements—viz., Grand Bassam, Assinie, and Porto Novo; also portions of coast unprotected by any European Power. West of Grand Bassam there is unoccupied coast of considerable extent; east of Lagos, beyond Leckie, and reaching to Old Calabar, there is the important territory at the mouths of the Niger. Quite recently the Germans have taken certain ports on this coast—viz., Ahgweh, Bageida, and Little Popo. At these there was a thriving and increasing British trade, and with the chiefs of Ahgweh and Little Popo treaties had been made on behalf of Her Majesty, securing the right of British subjects to trade on equal terms with those of any other nation. The occupation by France and the late annexations by Germany break the continuity of the British protectorate; there is an increasing conflict of the various national interests, and the influence of the British authorities with the natives is being lessened; the introduction of different principles of trading will also seriously affect the prosperity of British commerce. It is important to mention in this connexion that the duties upon spirits, arms, and ammunition levied in the British settlements furnish the greater portion of the Government revenue. In German and French settlements these articles are known, in most cases, to be free of duty, and being sold to a great extent in the same markets as the British imports, competition becomes difficult, and the loss to the British revenue and trade must ultimately be great. The Chamber would suggest, therefore, that while negotiations regarding African territories are pending, something might be done in the way of exchange or by mutual concession to induce Germany, at least, to withdraw from those newly acquired ports where British trade had become established, and where German rivalry upon different principles is likely to be so injurious. This Government might also be requested to take into consideration the question of the extension of the British protectorate to the unprotected portion of the coast named.—I am, &c.,

"C. B. Paris, President,  
"Thomas H. Barker, Secretary."', 'last_edit_date': '1885-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1885#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH TRADE ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"So much for the western frontier. On the east we are similarly threatened by the Germans. They started with the possession of a small station at Beh, the people of which had long been desirous of entering the protectorate, but their offers were refused by the Government. This year a Commissioner was appointed to define the frontier. A line was decided on extending due north from the coast for a distance of over three miles into the interior. On this decision the Germans immediately annexed the Krepe country as far as the banks of the Volta. The Krepes were formerly in the Danish protectorate when we acquired Quittah and all the Danish possessions. Krepe went with the rest, yet we have allowed the Germans to annex the place. The sympathies of the natives are solely with the British. These German annexations are made by the advice and on the surveys of the Basle missionaries, who have for years been subsidised and protected by the British Government. For the rescue of some of their mission the Ashantee war was undertaken. The importance of these annexations will be seen when one has a knowledge of the trade routes to the interior, as it is upon the trade with the interior that the colony depends. There are three routes. The western is up the Tando River. A very large trade is carried on here, Ashanti being mainly supplied by this route. The command of the River Tando is lost if we permit the French to dispossess us of part of Apollonia and Aowin. The central route is via Cape Coast to Prahsu and Coomassie. A small trade is done here, owing to all the carriage being by land. This route is in British hands so far. The eastern, which will be the more important route, as by it most of the Mussulman trade is carried on, passes by the Volta through Krepe. Unless the Germans are dispossessed of this country, no British trade will be done this way. I hope you will call the attention of your Society to the neglect of British interests by the Government, and to the need for instant action, or else the whole of the British trade in these parts will fall into the hands of other European Powers. If Ashanti is not soon included in the protectorate it will probably be French.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Colonial military structures in Africa involved African elites and were characterized by hierarchical organization and significant influence on political decisions.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles both provide insights into the claim that colonial military structures in Africa involved African elites and were characterized by hierarchical organization and significant influence on political decisions. The textbook highlights that colonial powers utilized indigenous personnel in their military establishments, aligning with the claim of African elite involvement. It notes that these armies, initially created for conquest and control, were maintained by new independent African rulers, indicating a hierarchical organization. However, it diverges from the claim by emphasizing that the European denial of command positions to Africans limited their political role in independence movements, suggesting a lack of significant influence on political decisions. In contrast, The African Times articles illustrate the involvement of African elites through examples like the appointment of Hon. George Blankson, J.P., as field-marshal, indicating a hierarchical structure. The articles also mention the organization of native forces and strategic decisions made in collaboration with colonial officials, highlighting military influence on political and military strategies. Despite this, the articles do not explicitly discuss the broader political influence of these military structures on colonial governance. Overall, both sources support the involvement of African elites and the hierarchical nature of colonial military structures, but they provide limited evidence of significant political influence, with the textbook particularly noting constraints on African political roles.

[{'document_title': 'African politics and nationalism, 1919-35', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The colonial regimes were no exception to the truism that every ad› ministration makes use of intermediary structures, largely for reasons of economy and effectiveness. The colonial governments made varied use, as R. F. Betts has shown above (Chapter 13) of traditional institutions and leadership elites to facilitate their control of the subject peoples. Indeed, in the search for such authority structures and personnel, the colonial officials often created new ones which they could understand and use. Such were the 'warrant chiefs' of South-eastern Nigeria, the native authorities among the Maasai in Tanganyika (now Tanzania), and in parts of Uganda outside Buganda, and most of the so-called chiefs (chefs de paille) under the French, Belgians and the Portuguese. [{'id': 205, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST', 'last_edit_date': '06-13-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_07_1863', 'content': "Reinforcements came from Sierra Leone and the Gambia, in Her Majesty's Ship Dart and Dover, to the number of about 180 men. Forty were sent to Accra, and the rest to the camp at Mansoo. The Anamaboes left the camp at Mansoo when they heard of the battle of Bobeecomah, and joined the army of the East. The Hon. George Blankson, J.P., was made field-marshal, and his son his aide-de-camp.

With one of the captives at Bobeecomah General Owoosookookoo sent a symbolical message to the Governor—two sticks, one short and the other long, requesting him to choose one. The meaning is, that if the Governor was in favour of the early termination of the war, he was to take the short one, and give up Ajaman, dead or alive; but should he take the long one, he (Owoosookookoo) would continue the war for the next three years, amidst all difficulties. The Governor, with his brilliant staff, moved to the field, and took his quarters at Denkara, a few hours from the Ajimacoo's camp. He retained the *long stick*, and sent Prince Osoo Ansah, one of the hostages of the last war, and brother to Owoosookookoo, to inform him that he will not open a negotiation with him unless he sends a chief or captain of importance, and that he retains the *long stick*, and would fight with the Ashantees for the next seven years, until the kingdom of Ashantee will come to obedience with the English Government. Meanwhile, he properly organised the native forces, compelled those who had retired from the field to rejoin the camp, settled all disputes and differences amongst them, and inspired new spirit in them. And after a consultation between him and Major Cochrane, they agreed that, should the Ashantees not come to their terms, a simultaneous attack should be made with the regular forces and the native armies—numbering at least about 25,000 men—against the Ashantee force in Soedrue, and either gain a complete victory over them, or compel them to retire from our territory. Owoosookookoo has received the Governor's message, and is still refractory; but he has sent up to communicate with the King. Already the Governor has given orders to the native force to be ready to advance at a moment's notice, and I hope by the next mail I shall be able to communicate something definite to you.

The Governor had given a commission, as captain of Volunteers, to Mr. Charles Finlason, who has raised a corps of Volunteers and organised them at his own sole charge. The Governor honoured this corps under Captain Finlason by accepting them as his bodyguard and escort.

Ensign Brien, of the Gold Coast Artillery Corps, has died of dysentery. There are strong complaints of cruel neglect in his case on the part of the medical officers. [{'document_title': 'Chiefs and Kings of the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The interest which your journal has always taken in the affairs of West Africa induces me to solicit a space for the insertion of this article, which I trust will not fail to lead to an amelioration of the state of things, by its being brought to the knowledge of those whom it concerns.

One of the results of the Ashanti Campaign was to bring the countries on the Gold Coast under the control or protection of the British Government. The countries on the sea-coast are divided into districts, to each of which a Commissioner is appointed by the Governor. The interior countries, however, are not thus provided for, but are left to be ruled by their chiefs and kings, as formerly. The authority of these kings and chiefs was not formally acknowledged, and any offence which, according to custom, is visited with severe punishment, is immediately reported to the Government authorities on the sea-coast; and the chieftain or king who ordered the punishment is brought before the Court and treated as the commonest fellow.

This action on the part of the Government terrifies and paralyzes a good many of these chiefs and kings, so that in a great many instances the wicked go unpunished. On the other hand, others use the name of the Government to acquire territories which they have not the least right to. Amongst these I may mention the name of one "Sakiaty," who is of great notoriety in Eastern Croboe, interior of Accra. This man was a chief of Odumase, a country of Eastern Croboe, before the Ashanti Campaign, but immediately after the war, he assumed the authority and title of king, which he said was vested in him by Sir John Glover for the valuable services he rendered in the war. Not contented with the throne which he has thus usurped, he is now intriguing to acquire Western Croboe also. The present king of Western Croboe, who is now being molested, forbears to say anything, lest his opposition may end in a contest, and he may be thereby brought to the sea-coast and treated with ignominy. But there is sure to come a successor who will dispute every inch of ground that "Sakiaty" has thus acquired. This will undoubtedly end in strife, when people will have the mortification again to see that their royalties are treated contemptuously by those who are their protectors. If the present system of government in the interior countries is to continue, I would, Sir, respectfully recommend that the following plans be carried out: (1) that every chieftain or king in the interior should prove his claim; (2) that the right of government by native chiefs and kings in the interior, so far as it is compatible with common sense and humanity, be proclaimed as supported by the British authorities on the sea-coast; and (3), that any unnecessary interference and aggression of one chief or king with another, be met with the highest displeasure of the Governor.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_08_1880#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We reproduce elsewhere two important papers relating to West Africa. One is a survey of the Oil Rivers Protectorate, furnished by an evidently well-informed correspondent of the London *Times*, on the occasion of Major McDonald and his staff sailing to inaugurate the new administration over 350 miles of seaboard and a large but undefined region inland. The other document is the Report of the Annual Meeting of the Royal Niger Company, describing the progress of settlement in their Niger territories. It is estimated that no less than half-a-million square miles are covered by their treaties or reserved to their influence by international arrangements. Both of these documents are interesting reading, as they speak hopefully and with justifiable confidence of development and progress. It may not be amiss to point out that, owing to the relative positions of these two British possessions, and the long frontier line which they have in common, the future of both largely depends on their administrators working together harmoniously for the common good. There is every reason to believe that this harmony will be maintained. Major McDonald has given many solid proofs of his capacity and tact; while the Niger Company have not only shown great administrative ability, but have successfully lived down the violent and, as it proves, unjustified attacks which were at one time made upon their policy and conduct. Major McDonald has a fine field open to him in the Oil Rivers Protectorate, which possesses a valuable and long-established trade, and can, therefore, with moderate taxation, yield a sufficient revenue for administration and development. We venture to hope that he will follow the example of the Niger Company in one particular—by largely using coloured agents in dealing with the native tribes. It is well known that some of the most useful work of the Company has been done by their numerous coloured officials. These have, when opportunity offered, ...

proved the capacity of their race, and amply justified the statemanlike policy of the Company in setting aside the absurd prejudices which have elsewhere hampered progress and civilisation. It forms a somewhat striking commentary on the criticisms which have been directed against rule by Chartered Companies, that one of these should have shown itself, in this important question, so far in advance of the majority of British Colonies in the tropics.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.62, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African rivers situate in the Bight of Benin, commonly known as the Oil Rivers, have been placed under the protectorate of Great Britain. The protectorate, announced at Bonny, in December last, by Admiral Sir Walter Hunt Grubb, extends from the right bank of Benin river to the Rio del Rey, thus including Brass, New and Old Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and other important trading stations.

Two series of considerations, the internal and external, have combined to render action imperative, and a retrospective view may not be uninstructive. Since the abolition of the export of slaves, these localities have been the sites of trading stations, palm oil being the chief article of export. The traders have been, with few exceptions, British, and the capitalists mostly Liverpool merchants. The natives allowed trading hulks to be anchored and commerce conducted on payment of fixed sums, known as "comey." Bonny, Brass, and Old Calabar are among the oldest of these trading ports, the native chiefs being also the native traders. They possessed numerous slaves who were sent with merchandise to the interior markets to collect oil, which was brought to the stations and sold to the whites. Among the Bonny chiefs was the father of Ja Ja, late King of Opobo; his son was brought up to the management of the business, and on his father's death he succeeded to his position. Of his enemies the most powerful was Oko Jumbo, who lost no opportunity to humiliate him. The Europeans could only let matters take their course; they regretted constant fighting of Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, but the relations between the Europeans and natives being strictly commercial, nothing could be done. Suffering reverses, Ja Ja was forced to fly with the remnant of his people after great slaughter at the hands of Oko Jumbo. He collected his scattered family, dependants, and slaves, and made his escape to the Opobo river. There Ja Ja found a place for his town, and established himself as King of Opobo.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Such, in brief, are the powers with which Major MacDonald is intrusted for the administration of the region to which he has been appointed. The “Africa Order in Council” referred to, deals with all contingencies likely to arise, in minute detail. In a region like that of the Oil Rivers, one cannot expect law and order to be enforced in the same rigid manner as in Europe, or even in the Cape, or an old Crown colony. Much must be left to the Commissioner’s tact and discretion. A body of Haussas are now being enlisted for the police service, and in time we may hope that the law will reach well into the interior, and that free traffic will be carried on without the intervention of middlemen. The numerous creeks and rivers form useful waterways, though they are hotbeds of malaria. It will be the business of the Commissioner and his staff, moreover, to encourage and even carry on experiments in the way of introducing new cultures and new industries. Major MacDonald has been in communication with Kew and with Sir Alfred Moloney, who has done such good work in Lagos. He will take out with him a large supply of seeds of various kinds, and begin by establishing an experimental garden at Old Calabar.

Major MacDonald’s own head-quarters will be at Old Calabar, where there is some kind of Consular building. But, of course, he will be pretty constantly on the move. His Vice-Consuls will be stationed as follows: General Hammill on the Bonny River; Mr. T. A. Wall at Old Calabar; Captain H. L. Gallwey on the Benin River; Captain F. Synge on the Forcados; Captain MacDonald on the Brass River; Mr. W. Armstrong on the Opobo River. Each of them will, of course, exercise jurisdiction on his own river, but Major MacDonald will be in constant communication with them, and it is hoped that very soon all the rivers will be connected by telegraph. The treasurer of the Commissionership is Mr. J. F. Roberts, while Mr. Tanner is Major MacDonald’s private secretary. There are besides four Consular clerks—Mr. Steains, Mr. C. Harrison, Mr. F. Wilding, and Mr. G. Quilter. This is a large staff, but not too large for the many duties which will have to be performed, in a climate where it is hardly safe to stay for more than a year at a time. It is hoped that the Customs dues to be collected will defray the cost of administration. Of course, the whole arrangement is a compromise. But it is to be expected that in time, under Major Macdonald, the progress made will be such as to justify the taking over of the Oil Rivers as a Crown colony. British connexion with West Africa has had many vicissitudes. Our colonies have been abandoned; have been made over to companies; taken over by the Crown, and generally treated without any sort of continuity of policy. Now that we have put our hands to one of the richest commercial regions on the continent, it is to be hoped we shall persevere in a policy of gradual development.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.614, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British possessions of the Gold Coast extend over a coast line of about 350 miles, and are separated from the colony of Lagos by a short interval, which is filled up by a wedge of German, two wedges of French territory, and the narrow strip of independent Dahomie coast, which was until recently under the protection of the Portuguese. The inland limits of the Gold Coast colony are vague, and variable in extent. Behind our actual possessions, our political influence largely extends, and might be exercised much to the benefit of the interior were we less timorous about asserting it. In spite of several alterations in our Ashanti policy, we may consider the Ashanti kingdom as within the sphere of political influence. It would not be difficult to extend British influence from the Gold Coast right up to the great bend of the Niger, and thus secure them to British commercial influence. When we think of how much has been effected in the consolidation and extension of our Gold Coast territories since 1871, we may confidently hope for a further extension and a great future for this rich and important possession. The littoral of the Gold Coast is of the same moist equatorial character in its climate and scenery. The typical West African forest country ends, however, on the northern frontiers of Ashanti, and the characteristic park-like grass land scenery of Central Africa begins in the plains through which the Upper Volta flows. Beyond the Volta and the countries of Gyaman, Ashanti, and Brono, the inhabitants are mainly Mahommedans, and belong to a stock related to the Mandingos, although there is a large infusion of immigrant Hausa traders and fighting men. In some of these lands a proportion of the Hausa constabulary of the Gold Coast is recruited. Although the inhabitants of the Gold Coast belong almost entirely to what may be called the Ashanti family, yet increasingly the Hausa language is becoming the commercial tongue of the natives, although English has a great hold and is extending. The influence of the Hausa, no doubt, is aided by the presence of the constabulary, who are either recruited on the Niger or at the back of the Gold Coast. A most valuable arm they are likely to prove. They are very brave, very sober, and very loyal to their white officers.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.611, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will be considered presently whether larger reductions cannot be effected in the cost for military establishments without endangering the security of the settlements, and with increased efficiency to their administration.

Admitting that there may have been errors in the administration of these settlements, that their finances may not have been always carefully managed, and that differences or collisions with the natives have occurred which greater forethought or judgment might perhaps have in some instances prevented, it cannot be denied that, from their circumstances and position, they are exposed to risks and embarrassments from which most other colonies are free, and that whenever settlements are brought into contact with warlike and lawless savages, such complications as have occurred on the West Coast are by no means unfrequent, and are generally productive of financial and other difficulties.

The possibility of introducing improvements into their administration will, however, presently form a subject of consideration.

The suggestion that the benefits accruing from the settlements would be as readily obtained were they abolished, or, at least, made trading posts with a consul, is supposed to be supported by the fact that the oil rivers, as the district is termed in which the Benin, Nun, Calabar, and Bonny Rivers are situated, have a trade in palm oil exceeding that of the settlements, and yet that it is sustained without any aid or interference from Government.

This statement is perfectly correct, except as regards the non-interference of the Government, the Commodore being compelled at times to exercise all the authority which the power of the squadron gives him to maintain order in these rivers, which are said to be occasionally the scene of great irregularities.

It must, however, be borne in mind that the district in question is most prolific in palm-oil trees, and that ready access is obtainable to it through its numerous rivers; thus favourably situated, Europeans had every opportunity of making the natives aware of the value of the produce that lay around them, and of inducing them to turn their attention to its collection, whilst the facilities which were afforded the trade were such as are not to be found in any other part of Africa.

Urged by these considerations, the chiefs were soon led to see that it was more advantageous to employ their slaves in the manufacture of palm oil than to sell them; and it is easy to understand how, under these circumstances, no Government aid should have been required to create the large trade that now exists, and by its agency has abolished the former traffic in slaves.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.605, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Royal Niger Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Amongst the questions which the French and British position in West Africa has brought forward for more or less immediate decision is that of the future of the Royal Niger Company.

The very great services rendered by this Company to the Empire hardly need, in the light which has been thrown upon them by late events, to be recapitulated. Organised originally under another name for the purpose of amalgamating British interests upon the Lower Niger, the first years of its corporate existence were devoted to the object of outstripping all foreign competitors for local influence, and especially to fighting with its own weapons an important French commercial enterprise organised under the auspices of M. Gambetta for the political purpose of establishing French rights in a region known to be one of the most valuable in Africa. Between the years 1881 and 1885 the Company almost ruined itself in defeating the efforts of France to gain possession of the basin of the Lower Niger. But although the struggle ran at moments so close, the result was entirely successful for British interests. The French houses withdrew from that portion of the river, and in consequence of what had been done Great Britain was enabled, at the Conference at Berlin in 1884, to take the position of the only Power having influence on the Lower Niger. The services of the Company were cordially recognised by the British Government of the day, and its position as a political instrument was greatly strengthened by the grant of a charter in 1886.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1897#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FRENCH EXPEDITIONS TO THE UPPER NIGER AND IN THE SAHARA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The European members of the expedition instructed to take possession of the country, which has been already placed under French protection between the river Senegal and the Upper Niger, and to make the necessary observations for a railroad between the two rivers, embarked at Bordeaux on October 5 on board the "Equator," en route for the Senegal.

The expedition is a very strong one, and under superior military command. There is a Chef d'Escadron, a captain of Engineers, a lieutenant of the navy, a lieutenant of artillery, a captain of Hussars, and a sub-lieutenant of infantry, Mons. Brosselard, who formerly belonged to the expedition of Mons. Flatters in the Sahara. These are the superior staff. In addition, there is an auxiliary company of workmen of the artillery under a captain, lieutenant, and sub-lieutenant. The chief command of the troops and general direction of the works between the Senegal and the Niger have been entrusted to a Chef d'Escadron of the artillery, assisted by a captain and a lieutenant of the navy. The troops consist of a company of workmen of the artillery, two companies of sappers and miners, and four companies of Senegal sharpshooters, in all about 700 men, which are considered to be sufficient to ensure respect and security.

In one of the late meetings of the Academy of Sciences, Colonel Perrier made the following observations on the subject of this expedition. He said:—

"A great expedition, at the same time military and geographic, has just now been organized in France, with the object of binding together definitively, by means of a railroad, the French possessions of Senegal with the basin of the Niger, and subsequently with the Soudan. The end in view is to convey commerce into the interior of Central Africa, to open an immense market for the productions of French industry, and to push forward civilization by means of communication always rapid and sure. It is the Minister of the Marine who has conceived the project of this vast enterprise, who has prepared the means, and who is charged to carry it into execution with funds already placed at his disposal by the Chambers. The chief command has been entrusted to the Commandant Desbordes, who will have under his orders soldiers of the navy, fighting men, and labourers in sufficient numbers to ensure the safety of the column, and to construct and hold the small forts which will dot the way between the Senegal and the Niger. To this column, which is purely military, is united a topographical mission, selected chiefly among officers of the army, and placed under the command of Commandant Derrieu, of the old superior staff of the army. It is composed of officers—astronomical, geological, and...', 'last_edit_date': '1880-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1880#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.608, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Germans in Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The plans for the Government Buildings for the Cameroons are now ready, and they will as soon as possible be put into execution, since the houses in which the officials at the Cameroons are at present residing are unhealthy and not befitting the position of their occupants. The site of the buildings is known as Joss Flat, on the left bank of the Cameroons river, and gives a comprehensive view of the Cameroons mountains, the sea, and the heights of the interior. The principal building contains a dwelling and a reception-room, a dining-room, the office, and five other rooms suitable for dwelling or bedrooms, with a room beneath for guests, a bathroom, and three servants' rooms. As with all buildings for Europeans there, the ground floor comprises an open hall. The house is only two-storied in the middle part, the rest being one story. The foundations will be made of a volcanic quarried stone to be found hard by, but bricks will be used for the structure, and these, together with the wood for the roof, doors, and windows, &c., will be taken from Germany. Native workmen from Accra will be employed. The total costs are placed at 66,000 marks (£3,300).

A letter has lately been received from Sergeant Biehlecke, of the Kaiser Franz Regiment, who was sent out to the Cameroons a few months ago to organize a police force, and who is at present at Bageida, in Toga-land. With Biehlecke are two other under-officers, who proceeded to West Africa for the same purpose. The little expedition was well equipped with various side-arms, carbines, and 20,000 cartridges. With these weapons a number of blacks are being exercised as a protective force. Biehlecke has, as at home, to make daily reports on all accidents, arrests, crimes, offences, &c., which are handed in to Consul Schmidt, his next superior. hh: The British colonial administration faced challenges in managing refugee crises, as seen with the influx of Zulu and other refugees, which significantly altered the demographic landscape of their colonies.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide complementary insights into the challenges faced by the British colonial administration in managing refugee crises, though they differ in specifics. The General History of Africa discusses the broader context of refugee movements during the British colonial period, highlighting the influx of Tswana-Sotho refugees into the Cape Colony during the Mfecane, which brought cheap labor and altered the socio-economic patterns of the colony. It also mentions refugees from the Zambezi valley moving into Southern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, and the creation of autonomous enclaves by refugees avoiding colonial control. However, it does not specifically mention Zulu refugees or their impact on British colonies, which is a notable difference from the claim. In contrast, The African Times articles provide specific details supporting the claim, describing the influx of nearly 200,000 Zulu refugees fleeing turmoil in Zululand and seeking asylum within British territories, significantly altering the demographic landscape. The articles highlight the British administration's struggle to provide resources and protection, as seen with refugees from the Dahomian attack on Porto Novo, and efforts to settle refugees in British Combo despite limited resources. While The African Times supports the claim of demographic changes due to Zulu refugees, it does not delve into the long-term social and political impacts, an area of potential interest for historians. Together, these sources underscore the broader challenges of managing refugee movements and their socio-economic implications during the British colonial era.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim regarding the challenges faced by the British colonial administration in managing refugee crises. The articles describe the influx of refugees into British territories, such as the Zulu refugees fleeing from the turmoil in Zululand and seeking asylum within British colonies. This influx significantly altered the demographic landscape, as evidenced by the nearly 200,000 Zulu refugees mentioned. The articles also highlight the British administration's struggle to provide adequate resources and protection for these refugees, as seen in the case of the refugees fleeing from the Dahomian attack on Porto Novo. Additionally, the articles mention the British colonial administration's efforts to manage these crises, such as the Governor's attempts to settle refugees in British Combo and the challenges faced in doing so due to limited resources. These details align with the claim that the British colonial administration faced significant challenges in managing refugee crises, which impacted the demographic composition of their colonies. However, the articles do not provide specific information on how these demographic changes affected the long-term social and political dynamics within the colonies, which could be an area of interest for historians studying the broader implications of these refugee movements.

However, the position would have been very different for the main source area of slaves, where, if we employ the same assumption as used above (that is, that the area contained one-third of the sub-Saharan population) the deficit would have been 15 per cent or at least a generation's growth.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': "'Native policy'", 'content': "These explanations and arguments in respect of shortage of personnel and the need to reduce cost to the barest minimum are themselves directly related to a more fundamental problem which dictated the adoption of the conjunctive system of administration by all the colonial governments in the twentieth century. Afigbo has correctly observed,$^{7}$ the end of the nine› teenth century in the colonies of British West Africa witnessed not just the systematic removal of educated Africans who had held positions of responsibility in the earlier decades: the same period also saw the systematic tightening of conditions under which Africans could become French citizens in Senegal and elsewhere. Until near the end of the nineteenth century, Europeans were far more likely to succumb to indigenous diseases, as is evidenced by the death rates early in the century among British West African forces which were nine times as great among the European as among the African soldiers. 76 Europe was not medically well equipped for its African ventures. [{'id': 213, 'article_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'full_section_title': 'RIVER GAMBIA', 'last_edit_date': '09-18-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1863#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_10_1863', 'content': "Sir,—I have not yet been here long enough to justify me in entering with detail upon the general state of affairs in this river, but what I have learned hitherto has been in favour of the Governor, but against many points of the administration, and in especial against the system.

As you have often exposed the do-nothing-good policy which prevails with regard to this river, I shall not say anything about it until I have become more intimately acquainted, which I shall do if I stay here, with what is not done that ought to be done, and with what is done that ought not to be done. But, from the aspect of Bathurst, and from floating reports, I do much fear that our national shortcomings are not few in this most northern of our African colonies and settlements.

One of the first things that struck me on my arrival was the groups of poor miserable beings squatted about the beach. These, I find, are all refugees—people who have fled here for protection from the countries which the Mohammedans under Maba have visited with fire and sword. The practice of these mixed Arab and African followers of the false prophet of Mecca conforms to the original practice of the hordes that overrun the fairest provinces of Asia, the north of Africa, and no inconsiderable portion of Europe in the middle ages. They are making a religious propaganda, conversion, or devastation of the country; and the death or slavery of each of the inhabitants who do not escape by flight is the invariable rule. And thus it seems some of the best portions of these countries are being destroyed—their industry annihilated, their populations slain, scattered, or enslaved. The Governor, I am informed, is very kind to these poor creatures, and attends to their wants as far as his means will allow. But the numbers are continually increasing, so that many will be literally starved to death, unless some more adequate supplies be obtained than those which are at present at the disposal of the Governor, Colonel D'Arcy.

As I have often heard from you of the Governor's extreme desire to populate British Combo, which is immediately adjacent, and seemingly a very fine tract of country, I cannot, however, understand why he has not immediately settled these people there. Perhaps that, too, requires some outlay at first that he has not the power to make."}, {'id': 298, 'article_title': 'Polygamy in Natal', 'full_section_title': 'Polygamy in Natal', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_01_1864', 'content': "But numerically the great bulk of the population is Kafir. They number nearly 200,000. Of these few, if any, are, or are descended from, Kafirs who were inhabitants of, or had any land claims in, the now colonial territory before its annexation to the British Crown. They are mostly Kafirs from over the present border; especially from Zulu Land, where great convulsions have taken place during the last twenty or thirty years. Panda, called the African Napoleon, endeavoured to bring all the Zulu tribes under his personal sway. The same policy is pursued by his son, Cetchewayo. Plunder, devastation, and bloodshed, have been largely at work. The Zulus who would not submit, or whose destruction was, from other causes, certain if they remained in Zulu Land, began to seek refuge within the colony so soon as the British authority was established there. When it was found that the otherwise all-victorious Zulu conqueror would not be allowed to violate...
**83**

the British territory, and to drag Zulu refugees from under its protection, the number of immigrants rapidly augmented. The real advantages of this secure asylum were soon known of throughout Zulu Land. Even the great conqueror himself has been glad to find safety there for one of his sons, whom the crafty and savage Cetchwayo, who has usurped the reality of power in his father's dominions, and destroyed all other blood rivals, would have slaughtered. The stream of refugees really fleeing for their lives has been constantly flowing into the colony, which has been more than once at the point of war with the Zulu tyrant because of the reception and protection given to these people, until their number now amounts, as we have stated above, to nearly 200,000 souls."}, {'id': 5848, 'article_title': 'THE DAHOMIAN RAID ON PORTO NOVO', 'full_section_title': 'THE DAHOMIAN RAID ON PORTO NOVO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_06_1889#article-4', 'issue_date': '03_06_1889', 'content': "From Lagos we learn that a descent has been made by the Dahomians on Porto Novo. King Tofa, the ruler of Porto Novo, fled to the British for protection, and a number of chiefs under the King had been killed, and many others, with their followers, had entered the British territory as refugees. It was reported that a deputation from the King of Dahomey had waited on the Acting-Governor of Lagos, asking him to take the country of Dahomey under British protection. The King had sent one of his chiefs as the head of the deputation to explain his Majesty's intentions and to show his good will.

About the middle of April, later news from Porto Novo is to the effect that matters are quieter there. Three French men-of-war have arrived at Kontano, and a number of troops have been landed, and the inhabitants who had fled at the approach of the Dahomians are returning.

The cause of the trouble is stated to be a grievance of long standing—namely, the closing of the trade routes to the interior by King Tofa, of Porto Novo. The Dahomians had frequently threatened that if the roads were not opened they would make a descent upon the place, and they ultimately carried out this threat. The presence of the French force in the neighbourhood will help in the settlement of the dispute.

Telegraphic advices received in London on June 4 from Lagos report that the French Resident official at Porto Novo was at Lagos, and that the occupation of Abeokuta and Dahomey was being freely discussed. These places are the great centres through which the bulk of the produce passes to Lagos, and any occupation of these places by a foreign nation would be regarded as a serious impediment to the British colony, since the interior markets could be tapped and the trade diverted to Porto Novo, a French protectorate, or, perhaps, other places."}]
