[{'id': 290, 'article_title': 'Renewal of the Ashantee War', 'full_section_title': 'Renewal of the Ashantee War', 'last_edit_date': '12-14-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_01_1864', 'content': 'The military department of this Coast are actively preparing to take the field against the King of Ashantee, who, about a few months ago, invaded our Protectorate. An encampment will first be made at Mansu, from which place the army will proceed to the Prah and build fortifications. The colonel commanding the troops (Colonel Conran) has divided the regular army into three divisions—the first division, under the command of Captain Mackay, 4th West India Regiment, to be accompanied by Staff Assistant-Surgeon Horton; the second division, under command of Captain Gabb, 4th West India Regiment, to be accompanied by Staff Assistant-Surgeon Steward; and the third division, under the command of Captain Thorne, also of the 4th West India Regiment, to be accompanied by Staff Assistant-Surgeon Gardiner.

To these divisions will be attached hereafter the local Militia, Volunteers, and native allies, numbering in all about 20,000 men, rendering each division about 7,000 strong. The staff of the 4th West India Regiment, including non-commissioned officers and band, will be attached to the first division as a general rule. From this you will perceive that we have commenced preparations in right good earnest, and that there is a fair prospect that the war will be prosecuted with vigour. But we need more troops.

The forts will be given over to the Navy during the campaign. There will be, for a time at least, three men-of-war at Cape Coast, one at Anamaboe, and another at Accra.

The detachments are being recalled to head-quarters, except that at Din Cane, and a day or two after the departure of the mail the first division will move for the camp.

It is reported that the King of Ashantee has moved from his capital, but I cannot vouch for the truth of the statement; one thing, however, is true—viz., that, at the assembling of his princes and chiefs in the late gathering, he swore, upon the valour of his ancestors, that no foreigners shall enter the Ashantee capital except as prisoners of war.

Deputy Commissary-General Blane arrived by the last mail from the Gambia to organise a land transport corps. Certain number of men have been received from each king, enrolled, and assigned a payment of 1s. 3d. per day. The system of the land transport corps is very good, but already there are complaints that the carriers are becoming refractory.

Two of the officers have been sent up to Mansu to prepare barracks for the men; their reports are not very favourable, the people having burnt down the old barracks on learning that the troops will move to that place. In fact, so much have things changed since last year, the war at present is very unpopular, and the inhabitants will not go into it with the same viras as they did during the last ill-managed campaign. Every one wants peace, and that trade should again be established; for this war will affect the credit of the principal merchants on the Coast.'}, {'id': 317, 'article_title': 'ASHANTEE WAR.', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTEE WAR.', 'last_edit_date': '01-13-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_02_1864', 'content': "TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Cape Coast, January 13, 1864.

Sir,—In my last, relative to the state of affairs in this Protectorate, there was an error which was occasioned by reports then afloat of an intention to garrison the forts by the Navy. It was stated that sailors from the three men-of-war which were lying off Cape Coast would garrison the forts at Cape Coast, Anamaboe, and Accra. But from a more perfect information I am able to state that Colonel Conran, although desirous of availing himself of the services of the Navy, is, nevertheless, greatly opposed to the forts being placed entirely in their hands, as was the case during last year's expedition. His reasons are perfectly in harmony with existing circumstances; for it cannot be supposed that the Navy on shore will take the same care and interest in preserving certain necessaries which will be required by the soldiers on their return from the campaign as soldiers themselves would do if left in the forts. The Colonel takes very great care of his men, and attends personally to the minutest detail of their comfort. Should, therefore, the necessity of the service require the landing of marines or sailors, it is supposed that an officer of superior rank in the Army will be detached from the camp to remain at Cape Coast Castle. Again, from the information which I have obtained from a source which is beyond a doubt, it is stated that the head of the Government here has received positive orders not to act on the offensive, but to dispose the troops in such a manner as to prevent any further invasion of the Protectorate by the Ashantees. There was a report lately circulated that the army of the King of Ashantee was on the move, and the disposition of our troops (the preliminary order of which, by the favour of a friend, I was able to forward you by last mail*), must reflect credit on the chief of the army at this command.

His Excellency the Governor has rendered every assistance in his power to the military. His well-known and well-grounded popularity has made the native chiefs contribute willingly to the Land Transport Corps, which, from all appearance, is now working admirably. They were at first insubordinate and troublesome, but soon found out their mistake.

Mansoo has been selected as a place particularly adapted for the formation of a depôt for the supply of the whole campaign with Commissariat, military, and medical stores. And in order that the object contemplated might be better carried into effect, three officers were sent up prior to the order for the advance of the 1st Division for special services—viz., Lieut. Mansergh, to prepare barracks for the troops and build barracks for stores; Ensign Bulger, to attend to the military store department; and Staff

* See our January number.—Ed. A. T.

Assistant-Surgeon Horton, to render professional services and to examine the sanitary condition of the town and its vicinity."}, {'id': 413, 'article_title': 'Parliamentary Intelligence', 'full_section_title': 'Parliamentary Intelligence', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1864#article-24', 'issue_date': '23_07_1864', 'content': 'HOUSE OF COMMONS, JUNE 21.**  
**NAVIGATION OF THE RIVER NIGER.**

Lord Elcho asked the Secretary to the Treasury whether it was the intention of the Government to grant a subsidy of 5,000l. per annum, or any other sum, to the Company of African Traders (Limited); if so, upon what conditions the subsidy would be granted, and whether it would previously be submitted to Parliament for approval.

The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that the noble lord the Secretary for Foreign Affairs, upon a similar application being made to him last year, declined to recommend that it be complied with. Subsequently he felt himself justified in doing so, but papers reached the Treasury showing that the company which it was proposed to subsidise would be engaged in general trade, and competing with those at present carrying on commerce with Africa. (Hear, hear.) He would not say that the demand ought absolutely to be refused; but most certainly it ought not to be granted without ample time and a great deal of consideration on the part of the House. The Government would decidedly not make any such proposal during the present session, and, on account of the important interests involved, it would be advantageous that the papers received by the Treasury should be published. (Hear.) For his own part, he had no hesitation in saying that he regarded the objections to the proposal as objections of very great weight.

**FRIDAY, JUNE 24.**  
**THE GLADIATOR.—STEAM TRANSPORT, ETC., FOR REMOVING TROOPS FROM CAPE COAST.**

Lord C. Paget thought that what he was about to state would be satisfactory to the House. The War-office had now made an arrangement by which, instead of the removal of 500 men from Cape Coast Castle, 700 men would be removed. (Hear, hear.) Of these 500 would go to the West Indies and 200 to Lagos. From Lagos 200 would be removed to Sierra Leone station. This had necessitated an alteration in the arrangements of the Admiralty. It was now proposed that the Gladiator should go straight to Madeira, and she had started that day. She would coal at Madeira, in order to be prepared to take in tow the Waubujeez transport, which would carry the troops. The transport would start from this country on Thursday, accompanied by the Bulldog, which would tow her out of the Channel, and go with her to Madeira, if necessary. At Madeira she would find the Gladiator waiting for her. The Gladiator would tow her to Sierra Leone, and thence to Cape Coast Castle. The Waubujeez would there embark the troops for Barbadoes; and the Gladiator, after towing her into the offing, if necessary, would embark the 200 men for Lagos, and from Lagos would return to Sierra Leone with about the same number of men to be stationed there. (Hear.) The Gladiator would thence return to England. (Hear.)

**TUESDAY, JULY 12.**  
**THE SQUADRON ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.**'}, {'id': 2566, 'article_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'last_edit_date': '09-01-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_09_1873#article-3', 'issue_date': '29_09_1873', 'content': "The screw steamship Warree sailed on the 13th for Cape Coast Castle and the River Volta. The harness which has been sent out provides for mule carriage of guns and stores, in case the nature of the country should forbid wheel transport; but the Royal Carriage Department is executing an order for 1,000 sets of man harness for dragging the guns and carts, and provision is further made for the most impracticable places by sending out bundles of poles to form bearers or stretchers on which goods may be carried in men's hands or upon their shoulders. Yesterday afternoon two waggon-loads of delicacies for hospital use, weighing in all four tons, arrived at Woolwich for shipment on board the Adela.—*The Times*, Sept. 16."}, {'id': 2633, 'article_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'full_section_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/31_12_1873#article-8', 'issue_date': '31_12_1873', 'content': "| Name of Ship | Where Loaded | Freight | Date of Sailing |

To these must be added the Warree, one of the first ships loaded at Woolwich, but not hired, as her freight was carried at so much per ton. **December 31.**—The Elizabeth Martin sailed last night, and now Her Majesty's ship Supply, two guns, has arrived at Deptford to take in stores for Sierra Leone and Cape Coast Castle. The Supply is a store-ship of 1,100 tons burthen, having engines of 265-horse power, and she has been fitted at Chatham for passage."}, {'id': 6684, 'article_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION', 'full_section_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_01_1896', 'content': 'It is understood that a movement is being made on Coomassie from the north simultaneously with the advance of the expeditionary force from the coast. Inspector O’Donnell, of the Gold Coast Constabulary, proceeded with 150 Houssas and two Maxim guns to the Koranza country, thence to threaten the Ashanti capital. One thousand muskets and a large quantity of gunpowder and lead were also sent to the north to arm the Koranzas, who have long been at war with Prempeh. Adonko, chief of Krobo, offered the services of himself and tribe, and a reply was sent to the effect that he could come if he brought 1,000 carriers.

The attitude of the neighbouring tribes is, on the whole, very satisfactory, evidence of their friendliness being afforded by the numerous and substantial offers of help which they made to the British authorities.

Major Baden-Powell and his force of 400 Elmina and Krobo scouts arrived at the Prahsu on Dec. 21. He has received orders to cross the Prah and clear the bush round the villages of Tobiassi, Esaman, Kuma, Fumsu, and Akusirem, and place them in a state of defence, so that when the troops advance, the stores now on their way to the front may safely be warehoused. These four villages are about six miles apart, Akusirem, the farthest north, being some twenty-five miles from Prahsu. At the same time it was announced that the Adansi scouts, who were sent across the Prah, were ordered to place pickets along the fourteen miles of road between Atobiassi, about a dozen miles north-west of Akusirem, and Dadiassi, a considerable village in the bush eight miles to the east of the road to Coomassie, thence to keep a close watch on the movements of the Ashantees.

Major Baden-Powell’s rapid march to the front is of some significance, as showing that the preparations for the advance of the force are not to be delayed by negotiations with King Prempeh.

Captain G. E. Benson, R.A., started on Dec. 21 for Prahsu, to take over the command of the Artillery. He has with him two Maxim guns, four rockets, and eight 7-pr. guns. Six of the 7-pr. guns will be taken on in advance, but the other two will be left at Prahsu. It has been decided to send guns on with the advance guard, as the Ashantees are in great dread of artillery. Some question has arisen, however, as to the advisability of taking rockets into the bush, as they might, by rebounding, prove dangerous to the force employing them.'}]

[{'document_title': 'Africa at the Meeting of the British Association', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the recent meeting of the members of the British Association, in the Geographical Section, Major Darwin, the Chairman, had a good deal to say about the development of Central Africa by means of railways. The great barrier, Major Darwin said, to the progress of colonisation was the belt of fever-stricken forest near the coast; and the problem was how to cross those malarial regions quickly into the healthy interior, where the higher type of Native was to be found. The slave-raiding in the interior also tended to impede progress; and the opening up of main trunk lines of communication would be the most effective means of counteracting the slave trade. To develop the traffic along the rivers and in the lakes was the first stage in the commercial evolution of a continent like Africa. But the rivers were obstructed by cataracts, and the construction of railways must, therefore, be the second stage. Taking the East Coast first, the first region to attract attention was the valley of the Nile and parts of the Central Soudan. The sooner this region was connected with the civilised world the better, and it was only as to the method of opening it up and as to who was to undertake the work that any question would arise. Below Berber the Nile was interrupted by cataracts for several hundred miles, while above that town it was navigable for 1,400 miles. The importance of a railway from Suakim to Berber was thus evident, and there was perhaps only one other place in Africa where an equal expenditure would open up such a large extent of country to European trade. Passing further south, the lines of communication next considered were those leading to the Victoria Nyanza, and on to the regions lying north and west of the lake. Two routes for railways had been proposed, one running through the British and the other through the German sphere of influence. The German route would be shorter, but the British line would open up more country to the east suitable for prolonged residence by white men. If the Germans wished to launch out on great railway projects in Africa, let them make a line from the south end of Lake Tanganyika to the northern end of Lake Nyassa, and thence on to the coast. Such a line of communication would be most valuable in putting an end to the slave trade, for it would erect a great barrier across the roads traversed by the raiders. Further south they came to the Zambesi River. This line had many faults. The whole valley was unhealthy, and white men would prefer a route which would bring them to high land more quickly. The Upper Zambesi valley was likely to be more attractive to white men. The Beira Railway would form a much better line of communication to this region than the river itself. The Congo afforded a grand opportunity of opening up the interior. From the coast there was 150 miles of navigable waterway, and afterwards there were 200 miles of cataracts, round which a railway was being made. From Stanley Pool there were 7,000 miles of navigable waterway, so they might predict a grand future for this route to the interior. The next great navigable waterway met with was the Niger. There was no area of equal size so densely inhabited, or where trade offered greater inducement to open up a commercial route. Little had to be done in this respect, for the Niger was navigable for light draught steamers 550 miles from the sea. The only drawback was the unhealthy nature of the coast districts which had to be traversed. At Lagos, a survey of a railway running in the direction of Rabba had been made, the objective being the towns of Abeokuta and Ibadan; and surveys had also been made for a railway to connect either Kormantin or Apam with Insuian. It was possible that those who selected this route were too much influenced by a desire to reach Coomassie, which was a political rather than a commercial centre. It was to be hoped that the merits of a line from Accra to Odumase would be considered before it was too late. For connecting the Upper Niger with the coast, the best commercial route would be a line running in a north-easterly direction to the Upper Niger. Such a line would connect the longest stretch of navigable waterway in this region with the best harbour on the coast. But the fact that it crossed the Anglo-French boundary was a bar to this project at present. The proposal to connect Algeria with the Upper Niger would be simple madness. The idea was thus to unite the French spheres of influence, but he was sure the French would not waste their money on such schemes. Concluding, the President said his object had been to prove that, notwithstanding the strides geography had made in past years, there was yet an immense amount of work ready for anyone who would undertake it.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AN INTERVIEW WITH MR. H. M. STANLEY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"There would constantly be an immense quantity of goods going up country by rail. At present, on the Upper Congo, Europeans have to content themselves with living in wattled huts or mud forts, roofed over with straw and grass, and there is, of course, great danger from fire. By means of the railway the State could at once transport about a dozen iron stations; and there would soon be erected houses, churches, and schools, all of iron. Then the native chiefs, seeing what the Europeans were doing, would build iron houses, and would likewise require iron warehouses for their goods. The Chief of Kintamo, for instance, already keeps all his goods in iron boxes; while the Chiefs of Old Calabar live in iron houses which have cost from £1,000 to £3,500 each. Then, again, there would be many steamers to be transported in sections, to be put together on the upper side of the cataracts. On the Upper Congo there are at present only seven steamers, mostly steam launches, but to carry on the enormous trade of the 7,000 miles of navigable waterway of the Upper Congo, large and swift steamers will be required, capable of stowing cargo and carrying passengers in comfort. Again, there would be a large trade in timber, and saw-mills would be required to cut it up, which mills would have to be taken up country by railway. Enormous quantities of powder and large numbers of flint-lock guns would also be in demand. All this is without counting the almost limitless trade to be done in cloth goods. I should say that within a reasonable number of years after the making of the railway there would be a trade of about £10,000,000 annually with the natives of the Upper Congo—all in barter."

Pausing here, Mr. Stanley went on to say that there was a sentimental side to the whole question which was worthy of reflection. "We have been enabled," he continued, "with our own modest enterprise to secure something like 1,000 carriers a month to serve us in a country that, when I began work there, absolutely refused to have anything to do with us. Already we have some 400 native soldiers—all of which proves that the natives are friendly and willing to lend their services to the white man for his purposes. When the State can better afford it—which will be not long after the railway is finished—it will be able to enlist 3,000 or 4,000 native soldiers for the protection of the country against the slave-traders. Those stations which are to-day so modest and unoffending, and dare not take arms in their hands against the organized slave-traders, will, in a few months only after the opening of the railway, be in a position to take the offensive and absolutely prevent them from ever setting foot in the Congo State."

"That indeed would be worth working for," I remarked.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1886#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ITEMS OF WEST AFRICAN NEWS', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The victory of the British had a most salutary effect in all the districts around.—We are glad to learn that the Lagos Railway is being pushed on very energetically, and about ten miles of the line completed, and an engine and waggons are running.—Accra was left by the Bathurst on March 5. News from the interior showed that all was quiet there. Captain Donald Stewart was up at Coomassie, and with him were 300 of the Hausa troops. The fort at Coomassie had not been completed. One or two ordinances which had been put in force in the coast town were causing some little friction with the Natives.

The British & African Steam Navigation Co.'s steamer Teneriffe, with mails and passengers from the South-West Coast of Africa, arrived in England on March 28. The Teneriffe called at the French port of Loango, near the entrance of the River Congo. This port, which but a short time ago was about the most important in the French Congo territory, is now being seriously interfered with owing to the silting up of the entrance to the harbour. So shifting is the bar that the entrance varies every few weeks, and at times small surf boats go aground when entering. The French are now making arrangements with the Belgians for the conveyance of their goods up the Congo on the Congo Free State Railway, whence they will be taken across country to the French centre of Brazzaville. Already the French have in this way forwarded quantities of their goods, and considering that they originally intended to erect a railway up the Congo from Loango, this new departure is regarded as most important and significant.", 'last_edit_date': '1897-04-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_04_1897#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH EAST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "It is just three years since the British East Africa Company obtained its charter, and since then many things have happened affecting the situation in East Africa. The original concessions have been greatly extended, the sphere of the Company now reaching from the German boundary on the south to the Jub river on the north, and from the coast to the Upper Nile basin in the interior. That is the sphere within which the Company is free to develop and establish its influence without interference from any other Power. In judging of the progress made it should be remembered that it is in a very different position from the sister company on the south of the Zambesi. The hindrances in the shape of climate, want of easy routes, hostile Arab slavers, and turbulent populations, add to the difficulties; as does the proximity of Germans with their irritating methods towards the natives. Nevertheless, considerable progress has been made. The port of Mombasa has been improved; a European town is growing up on the old site; a railway towards the interior has been begun; agents are established at all the chief ports; regular communications with these have been established; routes have been laid down as far as Uganda, while half-way a fortified post and trade depot has been built. The friendship of the natives has been quietly secured. Experiments in planting timber and in testing the suitability of other cultures have been carried out. A fair estimate has been obtained of the value of the Sabaki river as a trade route and a source of water supply, as also of the areas of land suitable for pasture and agriculture, and these estimates have been encouraging. The value of the Tana river as a trade route has been proved; this river leads direct to some of the richest parts of the Company's territories. British influence over Uganda and Usogo has been secured. In short, the Company has done much to establish trade, to render the region between the coast and the lake secure, to ascertain its industrial capacities, to abolish slavery, and to promote civilisation. Had Lord Salisbury seen his way to carry the vote for a subsidy to promote the construction of a railway to the lake, progress would have gone on at a tenfold rate, and the slave trade would have been doomed. When it is considered that the Company is holding these territories on behalf of the Empire, and that for a long time its expenditure must exceed its income, the proposed subsidy deserves consideration.", 'last_edit_date': '1891-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Now that the Germans have followed the English and French for purposes of trade into the waterways of Guinea, British merchants will be sure to pay greater attention to these river basins as providing outlets for the disposal of their goods in increased quantities. In this they will be assisted by the English-speaking negro traders, who, travelling from Sierra Leone, Bathurst, and Lagos, have had so much to do in introducing English goods into the interior. While land carriage remains difficult and expensive, on account of the want of proper vehicles, roads, and beasts of burden, the rivers and lagoons will continue to be used wherever practicable by the canoes and small schooners which, with a few steamers on the Niger, have up to the present time conveyed European goods from the coast. With the spread of Christianity and civilization will come better means of transit.

For many years a continually increasing trade has been secured by the merchants and African trading companies, whose palm oil, ground nut, and other stations extend along the coast into the delta of the Niger, and thence into the Nupe country. But little difficulty usually marks the voyage of the British vessel, and in most cases the landing of the goods is safely accomplished. It is the negro trader who receives, as a sort of middleman, the European merchandise which he has to sell on the spot, or transfer into the interior, who has to encounter a host of difficulties arising from the barbarous character of the country and the tribal jealousies which prevail. Hence, rather than encounter the danger of loss through the absurd country customs characteristic of many parts, the exacting demands made by petty chieftains in others, and the physical difficulties on land and water, the English-speaking negro confines his commercial operations to those rivers where he is tolerably sure of securing protection, because of treaties made between the English colonial governors and the native chieftains. If he goes beyond treaty ground, as he sometimes does, he may encounter loss, as the colonial authority is powerless to secure compensation without the exhibition of force. The colonial trader living beyond the English territorial boundaries connects the British merchant with the inland caravan traffic. These caravans bring various articles of African produce to exchange for European commodities from the coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMANDER CAMERON ON CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Jan. 14th, Commander Cameron, in the Rooms of the Incorporated Chamber of Commerce at Liverpool, delivered an address on "The Commerce of Central Africa." Colonel Paris presided, and there was a large attendance of members and others interested. Commander Cameron, who, on rising, was loudly applauded, said: What he wished to speak about was the commerce of Africa, and what would come out of the Berlin Conference, and other events which were now happening; for the Conference could not fail to be of great importance to British trade. Tropical Africa, except in a few cases, on the shores of great water-ways, was scarcely known. From the interior the difficulties of transport prevented any profit except on the most valuable products. The first idea of the trader seemed ivory. India-rubber was coming into use, and before he left the West Coast over £20,000 worth had been exported from Zanzibar in one year. Many valuable gums and spices were found in Central Africa. Africa was to all appearance, until a few years ago, the happy hunting ground of Englishmen; it was only those who voyaged who could really compete with us. Now all these things were changed, and on every side they saw a scramble for Africa. It was our duty to know as much as possible about the resources of this continent, and how the future of Africa was to be controlled by the Congo Free State, which promised to be the outcome of the Berlin Conference. Very great results were to be expected, and he might mention that, north-east of Victoria Nyanza, there was a plateau which might be colonized by Europeans, and whence trade might be put into some of the great producing centres of Africa. The trade of the Arab at Zanzibar was carried out by a system of advance. On the west coast there was a trade carried on by a few Europeans. In the last century the Portuguese had an enormous trade up the Zambesi, and in Zumbo Town there were the ruins of a cathedral and a university which had at one time 370 students. There were two other towns of equal importance. The great difficulty in this trade was the climate. At a conference in Brussels in 1876, the idea of an International Association was sketched, and the King of the Belgians had set himself steadfastly to work to further this great idea of promoting the civilization of the "Dark Continent." Nearly all the people of Africa were traders; the cultivation of the soil was relegated to the women. At Nyanza there were enormous assemblies of people, some of whom came to market 15 or 20 miles, travelling against the current of the Congo. From this locality he had brought home nutmegs that were of the greatest use in commerce. From the same region there came wild coffee. There were enormous districts where any amount of rice could be grown; you had only to "scratch the earth," and it smiled at you. At some of these interior stations whole caravans were supplied by small villages with wheat sufficient for a week's journey. The people of those villages were able to produce for from ten to twelve times their number with scarcely any labour. On the Niger we had utilized water traffic, and the Congo had a number of miles of water carriage which could be utilized. There was, at the same time, the great difficulty of getting from the coast to this system on the Congo. Various schemes had been proposed to connect Stanley Pool with the Congo by railway, and he believed that after the settlement of the dispute between France and the International Association, the French would construct a railway to Stanley Pool, or the Association from the left bank of the Congo, and they would then be able to have instant communication with the centre of Africa. Further south, the Portuguese were beginning to wake up to the value of their territories. They were now making contracts to construct a railway into the interior. It was their duty as Englishmen to look after that scheme. The region he was speaking of produced ivory, gum, cotton, and spices. The Powers at the Berlin Conference had recognized the International Association as practically a sovereign State. What they must strongly insist upon was free trade, and permission to reside and trade in the Free State. Another point was as to the mode in which future annexations were to be made. Annexations had been going on rather fast lately, and the Conference agreement was to the effect that when a place was annexed notice was to be sent to the other countries, and that people trading at such a place were to continue trading under the same guarantees as formerly. The following resolution was proposed by Admiral Field, M.P., seconded by Mr. Johnson (of the Stanley Falls, Congo):—', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Most Recent Action of the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The Chairman of the African-Aid Society has lately been urging especially on Her Majesty's Government, on behalf of the Society, the following among other measures, as requiring immediate decision and action upon the part of this country:—

The reoccupation of the Fort of Quittah. (We have from month to month pointed out why this is indispensible.) Her Majesty's Government admit the necessity, but plead want of troops. Now as thirty or forty men at most are needed for this duty, this is surely a sorry plea for such a country as Great Britain. If Governor Pine had been reinforced with another regiment, so as to place 2,000 men at his disposal—a force absolutely necessary if the Ashantees are to be constrained to peace or chastised in war—Quittah would have been reoccupied as a matter of course. There is scarcely any error so grave as that of half measures, with which in African matters we are unhappily but too familiar.

The extension to the Protected Territories and to the colony of Lagos of the facilities afforded elsewhere by allowing the prepayment of letters by means of postage-stamps, permitting the employment for this purpose of English postage-stamps until special ones be provided and issued, &c., &c.

Some arrangements by which the Coast between the mouth of the Volta and Lagos, and that at the mouth of the Congo, shall be so effectually watched by ships of Her Majesty's Navy, as to prevent the escape of any slaver, or any exportation of slaves from those parts. An exploration and survey of the River Congo throughout its navigable course, by officers and ships of Her Majesty's Navy, at the very next favourable season of the year for the ascent of inter-tropical African rivers. The importance of this cannot be exaggerated at the present time. Many slave factories in the river have been abandoned and broken up, because ruinous instead of profitable. The time for the establishment of legitimate trade on this noble river is therefore near; and the African-Aid Society think that immediate steps should be taken for expediting and preparing for that period, so that our merchants may lose no time in taking advantage of it, and may have dependable data for their guidance.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Possibilities of Trade with Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The comparatively small value of produce in comparison to its bulk will certainly not bear the cost of slave transit, for slave caravans encumbered with their food cannot cover a greater average than five miles a day. Therefore the ordinary products are gathered only for domestic use. Moreover, as slaves are still used as bearers of burden, surely the most sensible way of stamping out slavery is to build a railway covering the great trade routes into the African interior, which are as open as the roads from London to Edinburgh; so Mr. Consul Warrington reported to the Foreign Office years ago (1822), and which has been found true by Denham and Clapperton, and many others since. The latter travellers added: "The British flag always seems to have a peculiar power of protection in Africa north of the Equator." But a

the country is misunderstood at present, what is the use of piercing Africa if the climate is so deadly, as many make believe? I found it compare favourably with India, China, and America during seven years in and about the Bights of Biafra and Benin.

**The People and their Traffic.**—With the exception of some few nomadic tribes, the people live chiefly in large towns fortified by walls sufficiently strong to resist ordinary attacks, and round these towns cluster agricultural villages. The space within the walls is usually extensive, and interspersed with cultivated fields, rendering it difficult to estimate the population. In the towns markets are held every two or three days, and in some places daily, and attended by numbers from neighboring villages, and although the total of their dealings would appear trifling, still there is everywhere shown a strong love of trade. At these markets are exposed for sale produce of all kinds, besides native and European wares. Cotton and indigo are cultivated, and there is an extensive manufacture of cotton cloth, noted for its quality and the durability of the dye, which finds a ready market among the negroes of Brazil. Besides cloths, there are manufactures of saddlery, cushions, &c. The art of smelting metals is understood, and gold chains and ornaments are manufactured with taste and skill. The trade of the blacksmith is everywhere plied. At the 1851 Exhibition specimens of native copper ware, tinned inside, were exhibited. European goods are brought from Tripoli and Morocco, and are estimated to treble in value by the time they reach Kano, the great centre of trade. Goods find their way in limited quantities from the coast, but are subject to heavy exactions as they pass along. The goods are transported by caravan in packages varying from 60lb. to 100lb. on the heads of slaves, except where the rivers afford water transport. Stanley, than whom no greater authority upon the subject exists, seems never to tire of pointing out the advantages which must result from the formation of new markets in the Congo territory; and the decision of the European Powers at the Berlin Conference that Free Trade principles should be established at least for a term of years in the territory of the African International Association will do much towards the development of trade with parts not hitherto reached by commerce. The British Congo Company (Limited), the prospectus of which our readers will find in another column, which may be aptly described as the practical outcome of the Conference's decision, is now announced, with a capital of £500,000, divided into shares of £5 each. All these trading establishments are constructed mainly of corrugated iron, with iron framework, though the interior may be lined with timber. The houses are well built, well ventilated, and comfortably furnished, and have all the appearance of a bright, pleasant home. With every trading colony of any size—that is to say, where there are more than three or four trading houses—there is a medical officer, jointly paid by the various firms.

Perhaps in no body of Englishmen abroad has such an improvement taken place as in the class of men who now conduct the trade with the natives in West Africa. In former times we had the unscrupulous scoundrels and pirates who carried on the slave trade between West Africa and America. To them succeeded the scarcely more polished "palm oil ruffians"—the masters and crews of the sailing vessels which would anchor for about a year in some one of the Oil Rivers, fill up their ships with native produce, and then sail away again. The conduct of the masters and seamen of these trading vessels was often outrageous. The way in which those earlier traders treated the natives was simply regulated by the power of the natives to avenge ill-treatment. With the missionaries it can be imagined how these ruffians came in conflict; and so angry were they at the prospect of the missionaries protecting their victims, or interfering with them, that they bribed and frightened the native chiefs, and used every effort to prevent the missionaries obtaining any hold on the country. The increase of steam navigation, and consequent supplanting of these sailing-vessel voyages; the more permanent settlement of European merchants on shore, where they began to build houses; the establishment and growing influence of various forms of administrative Government; and, it may also be said, the spread of civilisation, refinement, and sobriety among the seafaring class generally, brought about a better state of affairs in the trading colonies of West Africa. Yearly the improvement continues; more and more the great trading companies of Liverpool and Bristol have realised that their interests are better served by men of good manners and refinement.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ARREST OF AN AFRICAN CHIEF BY THE GERMANS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British & African Steam Navigation Company’s steamer Cameroon arrived in the Mersey on April 28, from the west and south-west coasts of Africa. The postage is 1s. 9d. for each pound or fraction of a pound.  
No parcel may exceed 7 pounds in weight, 3 feet 6 inches in length, or 6 feet in length and girth combined.  
No parcel may contain a letter, anything explosive, dangerous, or likely to injure other parcels, or any liquid (unless securely packed in a proper case).  
The places in British Central Africa at which parcels will be delivered are as follows: Blantyre, Chinde, Chikwawa, Chiromo, Fort Anderson, Fort Johnston, Fort Lister, Kalungwizi, Karonga, Mlanje, Port Herald, Rhodesia, Tanganyika, Upper Shire, Zomba.  
Parcels for the places mentioned above will be included in the Mails for Cape Town despatched from London every Saturday morning. Parcels from the rest of the United Kingdom must be posted so as to reach London not later than Friday night. The Mails from Cape Town for British Central Africa will be despatched about once a month.  
The general regulations of the Foreign and Colonial Parcel Post apply to parcels for British Central Africa.  
Parcels are also transmissible from British Central Africa to this country.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-09-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_09_1893#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Native African Customs.—Advantages of British Protection', 'section_title': '', 'content': "### SPECIAL AGENTS FOR LAMPLOUGH'S PYRETIC SALINE:

hh: The British military expeditions in Africa were characterized by extensive logistical planning and resource allocation, indicating a strategic focus on establishing and maintaining a prolonged colonial presence.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that British military expeditions in Africa were characterized by extensive logistical planning and resource allocation, indicating a strategic focus on establishing and maintaining a prolonged colonial presence. The General History of Africa describes Britain's military imperialism as "spectacular and bloody," highlighting strategic operations from coastal possessions in the Gold Coast and Nigeria to counter French expansion and annex territories like Asante and the Northern Territories. The establishment of the West African Frontier Force in 1898 and the conquest of the Sokoto sultanate in 1902 exemplify the strategic military planning and resource allocation. The British use of diplomacy, military confrontation, and indirect rule to manage vast territories with limited European personnel further underscores their strategic focus on maintaining a prolonged presence. However, the text also notes the use of divide-and-conquer tactics and exploitation of African rivalries, suggesting a reliance on opportunistic strategies alongside logistical planning. Complementing this, The African Times articles provide detailed accounts of the meticulous preparation and dispatch of troops, equipment, and supplies, including the chartering of steamers and troop-ships like the Warree, Adela, and Dromedary, loaded with provisions, ammunition, and medical supplies. The construction of infrastructure, such as railways and rest-camps, and the deployment of specialized units, including engineers and medical staff, further highlight the strategic planning involved. The establishment of communication lines and use of local resources, such as carriers and mules, reflect a comprehensive approach to sustaining military operations, suggesting an intention to secure and expand British influence. However, the articles focus more on the immediate military and logistical aspects, without explicitly discussing long-term colonial objectives, which is a notable difference from the claim's emphasis on a prolonged colonial presence.

[{'document_title': 'European partition and conquest of Africa: an overview', 'section_title': 'Military conquest, 1885-1902', 'content': "Britain's military imperialism was equally spectacular and bloody; the African response, as will be seen in the following chapters, was also resolute and often prolonged. Both Brass and Bini were duly con› quered by the end of the century. By 1900, British supremacy in southern Nigeria was more or less assured. This was achieved in 1898 with savage and unnecessary bloodshed. Over 20000 Sudanese, including their leader, Khalifa 'Abdallah, died in battle. Secondly, owing to the revolutionary changes in medical technology and in particular the discovery of the prophylactic use of quinine against malaria, Europeans became far less fearful of Africa than they had been before the middle of the nineteenth century. 57 Thirdly, as a result of the uneven nature of the trade between Europe and Africa up to the 1870s, and even after, as well as the increasing pace of the industrial revolution, the material and financial resources available to Europe were overwhelming in comparison with those of Africa. Thus while . European powers could afford to spend millions of pounds on overseas campaigns, African states were unable to sustain any protracted military confrontation against them.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': 'Conquest and reaction in British West Africa, 1880-1900 > Southern Nigeria', 'content': "While the Yoruba, by and large, chose the strategy of submission, the rulers of the kingdom of Benin and some of the rulers of the states of the Niger Delta chose that of confrontation. Though Benin had signed a treaty of protection with the British in 1892, she none the less guarded her sovereignty with determination. This, of course, would not be tolerated in that age, and using the killing of the British acting consul-general and five other Englishmen on their way to Benin as an excuse, the British launched a punitive expedition of 1500 men against Benin in 1897. Though the Oba himself would have liked to submit, a majority of his chiefs raised an army to beat back the invasion. They were, however, defeated and the capital was looted of its precious bronze treasures and then burnt. 48 In the Niger Delta, as in many other areas of Nigeria, the British had signed treaties of protection with most of the chiefs by 1884. However, while some, like Calabar and Bonny, had allowed missionaries to operate in their states, others had not. Moreover, all of them were insisting on their sovereign rights to regulate trade and to levy duties on British traders. This, the new British consuls, such as Hewett and Johnston, would not tolerate. A typical example of the rulers who stood up to the British consuls and missionaries was Jaja of Opobo (see Plate 6.3). He insisted on payment of duties by British traders and ordered a complete stoppage of trade in the river until one British firm agreed to pay duties. The consul, Johnston, ordered him to stop levying duties on English traders. But instead of doing so, Jaja dispatched a mission to the Foreign Office to protest against the order. When Jaja still refused to comply in spite of Johnston's threats to bombard his town with British gunboats, Johnston enticed Jaja on board a ship in 1887 under a promise of safeconduct but arrested him and sent him to Accra$^{49}$ where he was tried and deported to the West Indies. The other Delta states - Old Calabar, New Calabar, Brass and Bonny - stunned by this treatment of one of the most powerful and wealthy rulers of the Delta states and divided internally, surrendered and accepted governing councils imposed on them by Johnston.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The East African coast and hinterland, 1845-80', 'section_title': 'Increased European pressures', 'content': "As we have already mentioned, during the period under discussion East Africa was part of a large informal empire under British control. Towards the end of this period, however, the rise of Germany as a major Western power was beginning to increase the competition that already existed. Outside the East African sphere, tensions caused by this competition were already beginning to appear. When King Leopold called an international conference in Brussels in 1876 'to discuss methods of peaceful and co- operative action to develop legitimate commerce and attack the slave trade',$^{62}$ the rivalry was already appearing on the surface. The international conference eventually broke up into jealous national sub-committees and Leopold went ahead with establishing his personal empire in the Congo. The steamer took out a large quantity of timber for the purpose of building houses, and also a large amount of Government stores for the use of the troops."}, {'id': 2566, 'article_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'last_edit_date': '09-01-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_09_1873#article-3', 'issue_date': '29_09_1873', 'content': "The regiments embarking for the West Coast of Africa for service with the Ashanti expedition will most probably be the 2nd Battalion 23rd Fusiliers and 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, both in Ireland. Neither corps is expected to embark before November or December. The 23rd are under command of Lieutenant-Colonel the Hon. Savage Mostyn; the Rifle Brigade under Col. J. R. Glyn, C.B. The officers detailed for duty with native Artillery during the expedition are Captain Rait and Lieutenants Saunders and Erskine-Wilmot, Royal Artillery, all of whom have volunteered for the service.—*Army and Navy Gazette*.

The Warree has arrived at Woolwich, and is loading. The time allowed by the Government for her voyage out is twenty-four days. The Warree will not stop at Elmina or Cape Coast Castle, but proceed some miles up the Volta, to a landing place more convenient to the Ashanti capital, Coomassie. Her decks are being covered with an awning of deals and canvas from stem to stern, as a protection against the powerful rays of the tropical sun; and the Gertrude, which sailed a week ago, was fitted with a similar covering at Devonport, where she put in for coal. The six and a half million rounds of ball cartridge required will soon be forthcoming. The export of so much ammunition has necessitated an order for a large number of boxes; and at first these were made of mahogany and teak, as usual when intended for exportation to hot climates, but, as they will not probably be required to endure for a very long period, Colonel Milward has, for the sake of expedition as well as economy, directed that the bulk of them shall be made of deal. Iron, however, is the material preferred in the manufacture of most articles intended for the expedition, and carriages and limbers for the 4½-inch howitzers have been made in the Royal Carriage Department of that metal. The little carriages, scarcely larger than wheelbarrows, are all ready, and appear to be strong, compact, and serviceable. They will go out in the Warree. There are indications that the troops which are to be sent out to the Gold Coast for this expedition will embark at Woolwich in one of Her Majesty's troop-ships—probably the Tamar.—*Daily News*, Sept. 8. [*If she can get into the river, which we hope, but which is by no means certain.—Ed. A.T.*]

Several hundred cases of arms and accoutrements for the native troops on the Gold Coast have been embarked on board the Warree, the belts and pouches, as well as the rifles and bayonets, being all of the old-fashioned kind, which have been lying in store since the Army was supplied with more modern weapons and appurtenances. Her freight consists principally of provisions from the Royal Victoria Victualling Yard, Deptford, and hospital stores from the Control warehouses, in Her Majesty's Dockyard, Woolwich. In addition to the articles already mentioned, there have arrived at Woolwich, for shipment on board the Adela, a number of hogsheads, containing 2,000 sets of pouches and accoutrements for the native troops, and a hundred clearing hatchets for the pioneer work of the expedition. The harness which has been sent out provides for mule carriage of guns and stores, in case the nature of the country should forbid wheel transport; but the Royal Carriage Department is executing an order for 1,000 sets of man harness for dragging the guns and carts, and provision is further made for the most impracticable places by sending out bundles of poles to form bearers or stretchers on which goods may be carried in men's hands or upon their shoulders. Yesterday afternoon two waggon-loads of delicacies for hospital use, weighing in all four tons, arrived at Woolwich for shipment on board the Adela.—*The Times*, Sept. 16."}, {'id': 2588, 'article_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_10_1873#article-3', 'issue_date': '30_10_1873', 'content': "October 22.—The mail from the Gold Coast, with Sir Garnet Wolseley's first report to the Foreign-office relative to the forthcoming expedition, is expected about the end of the present month, and no other cargo of stores, except such as are taken by Her Majesty's ship Active and other ships which may be going out for particular service, will be sent until the arrival of his requisitions. The pier and the wharf at the Royal Arsenal are much encumbered by the railway materials for the proposed line, but there are no preparations yet made for their embarkation. There appears to be fully a ship-load ready, and barges are arriving daily with rails and sleepers. A few stores of other
193

kinds are being sent in for shipment, including a thousand of the pocket filters, with one of which every English soldier is to be provided; but, as far as can be seen, there is very little being done in the way of preparation. It is considered that all the material clearly necessary to be furnished for a campaign of such expected dimensions were provided in the first issues, and that all that remains to be done is to supplement those issues by two or three ship-loads of such special stores as the commander of the expedition may think requisite before commencing operations. If both the regiments selected for the service—the 2nd Battalion of the 23rd Regiment and the 2nd Battalion of the Rifle Brigade—are sent out, which will depend upon Sir Garnet Wolseley's despatch, two ships will be required solely for their transport. They have not been yet supplied with their Gold Coast outfit, but everything is ready for issue at a moment's notice at the Royal Army Clothing Depot at Pimlico. Large quantities of provisions are also being prepared at the Royal Victoria Victualling Yard, Deptford, chiefly salt beef and pork, but the suitability of salt pork as a diet for Europeans in a climate like that of the West Coast of Africa has been so much questioned, that it is considered improbable that any more will be sent out. It is most likely that the bulk of the provisions which are to follow will consist of Australian beef and mutton or English meat preserved in a similar manner."}, {'id': 2612, 'article_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_11_1873#article-5', 'issue_date': '29_11_1873', 'content': '## ASHANTI WAR PREPARATIONS.

**November 1.**—The Government have chartered another steamer, the Joseph Dodds, which will carry 1,000 tons of cargo. She has come to Woolwich, and is taking in railway material. The Lilian has finished loading, and sails immediately. The Government have purchased the Briton steamer for carrying stores to Cape Coast.

**November 4.**—Railway trucks are arriving at Woolwich for the Cape Coast and Coomassie railway; 1,000 pocket filters were also received yesterday. The Victor Emmanuel, hospital ship, is in a forward state of preparation.

**November 5.**—A monster distilling apparatus, consisting of a set of cisterns and about 4,000 feet of galvanized iron pipe, for distilling and condensing sea, marsh, and bush water, so as to make them useful for drinking purposes, are being sent out to the Gold Coast from Woolwich, for use either at Cape Coast Castle or at some other station, as the commander of the expedition may direct. The largest of these cisterns will contain about 6,000 gallons, and it has been stowed away in the fore-hold of "Transport No. 5," as the Joseph Dodds is officially called. The quantity of provisions sent out in this ship is enormous. Ten heavily-loaded lighters have come from Deptford Victualling-yard alone, and have discharged, or are discharging, their cargoes into the spacious holds of the vessel. These provisions are of various kinds. One large load consisted of 1,400 cases of preserved mutton, and 500 casks of salt pork; another consisted of 2,000 kegs of rice; and altogether it is estimated that the ship will carry out food enough to feed an army of 10,000 men for two or three months. Besides ordinary provisions, several van-loads of medical comforts arrived yesterday at Woolwich, and were put on board the same ship. They consisted of jams and jellies, potted fruits, preserved meats, and other delicacies, for the use of the sick and wounded in the hospitals, with large quantities of wine and bottled beer.

**November 7.**—The 28th Company of Royal Engineers are to embark in the Himalaya, troop-ship, for Cape Coast, under the command of Captain R. O. Jones. They are to be employed in laying down the railway. Mules are to be purchased at Madeira, and sent down to Cape Coast for transport service; several hundred sets of pack saddles, &c., are now preparing for shipment. The purchase of buck-shot has now ceased, Government making it for themselves, by which it is said they save 10/. per ton

**November 10.**—The Active sails to-day from Plymouth. The steamship Briton has been re-christened, and is now the Dromedary. The Marion has been despatched with stores, and the Dromedary, late Briton, is loading as rapidly as possible.

**November 26.**—The 42nd Highlanders (having its strength made up by two officers and 110 men from the 79th) will be sent out to Cape Coast about the 1st December. They will go by the steamer Sarmatian, one of the Allan line of American steamers which has been chartered by the Government for that purpose. The 2nd Battalion of the 4th Regiment, it is said, will be also despatched to the Gold Coast."}, {'id': 2633, 'article_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'full_section_title': "Gaboon River—The Cannibal 'Fans'", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/31_12_1873#article-8', 'issue_date': '31_12_1873', 'content': "**December 13.**—After two days' detention by the fog on the river, the Thames left Woolwich yesterday at 5 A.M. These boats are contrived on a novel plan, and those which were sent out early are said to have answered admirably, the cargo of the Bonny having been landed by them in four days, which was quick work. One of these, containing twenty-five beds, and said to be worth 1,100l., is about to be taken to pieces, in order to be conveyed to the Gold Coast for military purposes."}, {'id': 6684, 'article_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION', 'full_section_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_01_1896', 'content': 'The Special Service Corps under Lieut.-Col. the Hon. F. W. Stopford, a detachment of Royal Engineers under Captain Phillips, and of Medical Staff Corps under Surg.-Major W. O. Wolseley, left Aldershot for the Gold Coast, on Dec. 7. Shortly after half-past nine the special corps paraded with the detachment of Royal Engineers. He reminded them that they had been selected from distinguished regiments, and as a corps he hoped they would uphold the honour and integrity of the British Army. The Bathurst, with the second portion of the expeditionary force under the command of Sir Francis Scott, arrived at Sierra Leone on Dec. 8. All the officers and men are well and in good spirits. She experienced fine weather during the voyage, and the health of the troops is excellent.'}, {'id': 6684, 'article_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION', 'full_section_title': 'THE ASHANTI EXPEDITION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_01_1896', 'content': 'The Bathurst, with Sir Francis Scott and staff and the second portion of the expeditionary force, arrived at Cape Coast Castle on Dec. 13, and the landing of troops and stores was at once begun. There were also on board 250 carriers in charge of Captain C. H. W. Donovan, of the Army Service Corps. The work of engaging carriers has been proceeding without a hitch. Preparations for the expedition are otherwise well advanced. The rest-camps for the troops and the field telegraphs between Cape Coast Castle and Prahsu had been completed, and a detachment of engineers started immediately to examine the rest huts on the road and inspect the bridge over the river at Prahsu. Strong guards of Houssas have been stationed along the frontier, all the Houssas force being employed in lining the borders, with the exception of the men retained to guard the towns. Natives come down to the coast in large numbers, and the gold mines in the Wassaw country have been closed, as the Fanti miners, in dread of the Ashantees, are leaving their work to seek protection. The carriers have been working satisfactorily as far as Manso, but the difficulty of procuring food in the country beyond has retarded further progress. Two thousand loads have, therefore, been forwarded to that station. Captain Thring in charge of the transport service, and Lieut. Armstrong, Army Service Corps, start immediately for Manso.
