hh: Colonial expeditions in West Africa, such as the 1841 Niger Expedition and the Timbo expedition under Dr. Gouldsbury, often failed due to poor organization, planning, and inadequate data collection.
result: The claim that colonial expeditions in West Africa, such as the 1841 Niger Expedition and the Timbo expedition under Dr. Gouldsbury, often failed due to poor organization, planning, and inadequate data collection is supported by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. While the General History of Africa does not specifically mention these expeditions, it provides insights into the broader challenges faced by colonial endeavors, such as technical mistakes, manpower shortages, opposition from local traders, and hostility from Africans, as exemplified by the failed agricultural colonization scheme in Waalo. It also highlights the inadequacies in medical knowledge and the impact of tropical diseases, which could contribute to expedition failures. In contrast, The African Times articles directly address the 1841 Niger Expedition and the Timbo expedition, describing them as poorly organized and hastily conceived, with inadequate supplies and faulty planning. The Niger Expedition achieved no commercial or geographical success, while the Timbo expedition faced logistical challenges, such as the refusal to use canoes, leading to reliance on land routes. The articles further emphasize the lack of commercial information and knowledgeable individuals about African trade, underscoring the inadequacy of data collection. Together, these sources illustrate the common challenges faced by colonial expeditions in West Africa, highlighting issues of poor organization, planning, and data collection as significant factors in their failures.

[{'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': "'Native policy'", 'content': "These explanations and arguments in respect of shortage of personnel and the need to reduce cost to the barest minimum are themselves directly related to a more fundamental problem which dictated the adoption of the conjunctive system of administration by all the colonial governments in the twentieth century. This was the failure of the assimilationist or direct administration policy which was the vogue in the nineteenth century. Whether in respect of the French in the Four Communes of Senegal or of the British with regards to the Crown colonies of Sierra Leone, Gold Coast (now Ghana) and Lagos (in what is now Nigeria), assimilation had, by the end of the nineteenth century, been frustrated not only by the cultural resistance of the African peoples concerned. There was also a loss of enthusiasm on the part of the French and the British colonial officials themselves, due to the emergent trend of conflict and friction between the European colonial elite and the locally produced western-educated Africans. In both the French and British colonies, the end of the nineteenth century was marked by a systematic frustration of westernized Africans' expectations. As A. E. Nevertheless, tropical medical schools were established in Europe as early as 1897 in Liverpool and London, 1900 in Hamburg, 1901 in Brussels, followed later by Paris, Bordeaux and Marseilles, and in Africa by 1912 in Cape Town and 1918 in Dakar.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': 'The causes of failure', 'content': "Every case of resistance and armed insurrection went down to defeat, at least if one considers only the results at the scene of action. The second was the failure of the move to establish plantations in West Africa. This failure was caused by a number of factors. Another factor was the opposition that any attempt to seize any large areas or introduce large-scale forced labour for plantations would have generated among West Africans.$^{21}$ It was a combination of these factors that saved the people of British West Africa from the expropriation of their lands that was the fate of some of those in British East and Central Africa.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'States and peoples of the Niger Bend and the Volta', 'section_title': 'Political and institutional upheavals > Summary', 'content': 'Thus, in the centre and the north of the region covered in this chapter, existing political structures went into in a state of increasingly rapid decline in the nineteenth century and in some cases came to be dominated by new forces which had arisen mainly as a result of the Sokoto djihäd. Indeed, the most fundamental and dramatic - though tragic - of these changes took place in the much shorter period from 1890 to 1910, the period that saw the conquest and occupation of virtually the whole continent of Africa by the imperial powers and the establishment of the colonial system. In short, by as late as 1880, about as much as 80% of the continent of Africa was being ruled by her own kings, queens, clan and lineage heads, in empires, kingdoms, communities and polities of various sizes and shapes.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'During the period 1880 to 1914, the whole of West Africa, with the sole exception of Liberia (see Chapter 2), was brought under colonial rule. This phenomenon which meant essentially the loss of African sovereignty and independence as well as land, was accomplished in two phases. The first phase lasted from 1880 to the early 1900s, and the second from the early 1900s to the outbreak of the First World War in 1914. Each of these phases saw different European activities which produced different initiatives and reactions on the part of the Africans. It should be emphasized that these reactions were very much determined by the local African situation. Another equally important variable was the method adopted by the European imperialists in the establishment of their control over the area between 1880 and 1914.

This was the classical era of treaty-making in practically every nook and corner of West Africa followed in most cases by military invasions, conquests and occupation by armies of varying sizes and discipline. The period from 1880 to 1900 was the high-water mark of European conquest and occupation of West Africa. This completely disrupted the farm calendar though the precariousness of the rains made farming times particularly important. These associations used newspapers, plays, tracts and pamphlets as their main weapons.$^{7}$ ' Examples of such bodies, which acted as watch dogs of colonial rule, were the Aborigines Rights Protection Society (ARPS) formed in the Gold Coast in 1897, the Young Senegalese Club founded in 1910, and the Peoples Union and the Anti-Slavery and Aborigines Protection Society formed in Nigeria in 1908 and 1912 respectively. The ARPS was easily the most active. It was formed to protest against the Land Bill of 1896 which was to give control of all so-called waste or unoccupied lands to the government. As a result of a delegation it dispatched to London in 1898 which met the Secretary of State for Colonies, this obnoxious Bill was withdrawn. [{'id': 435, 'article_title': 'Navigation of the River Niger', 'full_section_title': 'Navigation of the River Niger', 'last_edit_date': '08-23-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1864#article-21', 'issue_date': '23_08_1864', 'content': "Gentlemen,—Before I explain to you, as far as I am able at present, the course which we propose to adopt, with a view to opening up the trade of Central Africa by means of the River Niger, it may be as well to give first a short statement of what has been heretofore done with that object.

It was in the year 1830 that Mr. Richard Lander traced the course of the River Niger down to the sea. The River Niger is distinguished from all other rivers in this respect, that whereas a great deal of curiosity always has existed about the sources of other rivers (more particularly the Nile, which has recently been solved, or is said to have been solved) with regard to the Niger it was as to the course which that river took after it left Timbuctoo. It was known to rise in the mountainous regions not far from the Atlantic, and to proceed in an easterly direction to Timbuctoo, and there this immense body of water was lost sight of, and was supposed for a long time to be swallowed up in the sands of the Great Desert. But by the enterprise and efforts of British travellers, and with fearful sacrifice of life, the question was at last solved by Mr. Richard Lander, who in the year 1830 followed its course in a boat down to the sea. Therefore, in 1832, a company was formed—a mercantile company—in Liverpool, to open up the commerce of the interior by means of the Niger. The expedition was attended with a total loss of the capital embarked in it, and with a fearful sacrifice of human life; in fact, I have in my eye now my friend Mr. Hector, who I believe is the sole survivor of that expedition.

Well, during the years 1839 and 1841 the enterprise was taken up by Mr. Robert Jamieson, who sent out a steamer and navigated that river with very great success as far as proving its capabilities for steam navigation, but, unfortunately, with very great loss as regarded the capital embarked in it.

Following upon that Her Majesty's Government sent out in the year 1841 an expedition, which is popularly known as the Niger Expedition. It was fitted out with great pomp and circumstance, under the auspices of Prince Albert and a great many philanthropic, and benevolent, and religious gentlemen, who took great interest in this expedition. But it produced no commercial result at all. The arrangements were conceived in such a faulty manner, and everything connected with it so badly organized, that it literally accomplished nothing. It neither added to our knowledge geographically, nor did it, in fact, attempt to do anything commercially."}, {'id': 4298, 'article_title': "Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition an Utter Failure", 'full_section_title': "Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition an Utter Failure", 'last_edit_date': '09-07-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1881#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_10_1881', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES._

Bathurst, River Gambia, September 7th, 1881.

Dear Sir,—That coming events cast their shadows before them, no reasonable mind can gainsay; just after this manner, we have been able to predict, almost to a certainty, that the expedition to Timbo, under the leadership of Dr. Gouldsbury, would leave in the annals of the history of West Africa much to be deplored.

But for the exertions of Mr. Berkeley and Mr. Thomas Brown, the expedition would have collapsed ere it left the Gambia. In truth, it might be said that to those two gentlemen the praise is due for the starting of the expedition at all. Before the expedition started, Dr. Gouldsbury had so much pared down everything to starvation point, that both the policemen and carriers, in their deep distress and mortification, were to be heard soliloquizing, as they were being shipped on board the St. Mary, the painful utterance of the children of Israel to Moses in the wilderness. Starvation, with the police and other labourers, began before they were landed at Yarbutender, the starting-point of the expedition.

It would appear that Dr. Gouldsbury, not satisfied with the arbitrary power wielded by him at the Gambia, carried his despotism into the interior of Africa.

In the _West African Reporter_, published at Sierra Leone, a copy of which I herewith enclose, it is reported that the King of Timbo had sent a message to Governor Havelock, complaining that Dr. Gouldsbury had carried away from one of his towns a slave-woman, much to the annoyance of both king and subjects, the result being that Dr. Gouldsbury's horse was seized by order of one of the chiefs.

_The Reporter_ pertinently says that Dr. Gouldsbury could not have been actuated by humane feelings in the matter, because, as...

he had been so, he would not have left behind one of his carriers, who has been found in one of the interior towns in very bad condition. No sooner had the news of the man having been found reached Governor Havelock, than he at once despatched some one to go and fetch him down. We hope soon to hear of his safe arrival at Sierra Leone.

The King of Timbo grew so indignant at Dr. Gouldsbury's conduct that he has at last, and much against his wish, invited the French to his country.

We learn that already a French mission has gone to Timbo, and, we fear, within a month or two hence the place may become a French protectorate.

We have spent over 2,000l. on account of the expedition to Timbo, and the result has been a gain not to the West Coast, but to Dr. Gouldsbury only, who, by the way, receives in shape of travelling allowance, besides his full salary, upwards of 400l.

We have to thank the home authorities for sending us such men as Dr. Gouldsbury; he belongs, we have no doubt, to the class relative to which a well-known statesman remarked not many years ago: "We cannot give you our best men, and you must content yourself with those we send you;" or words to that effect.—I am, &c.,'}, {'id': 4353, 'article_title': "A Snubbed Colony—Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition", 'full_section_title': "A Snubbed Colony—Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition", 'last_edit_date': '11-20-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-2', 'issue_date': '02_01_1882', 'content': 'The writer has advocated the development of trade from the Gambia, as far as you can go by water, towards the Upper Niger, then to work the portage by caravans for a few years, to be followed by bullock-waggons. Then, if the trade paid, make a horse tramway; this, if profitable, to be followed by a railway. That latter may be fifty years in the womb of Time.

Dr. Gouldsbury says that the natives of Garboo, its towns, and the towns to the north, wish to carry on trade with Yarbutenda, and the roads to be kept safe. Who is to do it? Were the Government to put a block house at Yarbutenda, with a garrison of, say, twenty men, with orders to patrol the roads and put down marauders, then trade would be safe, the natives would flock in.

The report is bald and deficient in original information; that may be because it is an "official report." Dr. Gouldsbury can write, I know. I trust he will explain and enlarge his "report" by publishing a pamphlet or a book. Lieut. Dumbleton's charts, itinerary, and notes, are the pith of the report, but they are but pure geography, at the same time the charts, notes, &c., are really good. We have not any information as to products beyond what has long been known.

Geology is only represented by the remark that ironstone exists under some hills; how about other strata, rocks, &c? Are there any granite rocks in the mountains from Cardy to Timbo? Any quartz measures? In the lower grounds have any coal measures been detected?

Botany is undescribed, except by long grass, fan and oil palms. Zoology is represented by horned cattle, goats, and sheep. They have not had time to observe other animals, plants, or birds.

This expedition, conceived in haste, planned at full speed, and carried out to, if possible, get ahead of season and time, appears to be but a counter-move of a weak nature to the expeditions of the French from Senegal to the valley of the Upper Niger. It rushed through the country, regardless of utility, making treaties, giving presents to all "by order," trying to get ahead of the rainy season, and what have we got for it?

Lieutenant Dumbleton's survey! The wonder is that with such undue haste he was able to make so good a one.

The expedition started at least two months too late under such orders that no one can blame Dr. Gouldsbury for the speed he tried to go at. He should have started early in November, 1880. That the report should be deficient in commercial information is not to be wondered at when we consider that from the leader to the carriers there was not a man cognizant with trade in Africa, especially with this portion of it—unless we take the ill-remunerated interpreter, Sulliman Waggy, who is a native trader, as an exception. However, the Report of the Expedition will please the M.P.'s; they will praise it to their constituents the B.P. Things will thus be "pleasant all round" no matter what becomes of Gambia.—Your obedient servant,  
Frederic Speer.

---'}]

[{'document_title': 'THE EXPEDITION FROM GAMBIA TO TIMBO', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is to be feared the party forming this expedition has come to grief. The report in the Upper Gambia last month, through native sources, was that much sickness prevailed among the party; that Dr. Gouldsbury and his officers were very ill; many of the men also, some of whom had died; that the men were short of food and almost starving.

Now it is well known here that though the leader and his officers were fairly supplied from England with provisions, the rank and file were not well supplied; and the amount of trade goods carried with them for the purchase of provisions from the natives was insufficient, and not of the proper kind. Also the medical stores sent from England were deficient in necessary articles, and in quantity, the bulk being medicines more suitable for hospital practice at home than an expedition in the tropics. Also Dr. Gouldsbury sent back the boats he had with him without replacing them with canoes; thus he is deprived of the advantage of water carriage. We fear that the economy system, that has done so much harm to Gambia, will have ruined this expedition. The last news heard of the party was, they were trying to work down towards Sierra Leone, without going to Timbo.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-04-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1881#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.723, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "A Snubbed Colony—Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Well, his lordship sends us an answer through the Administrator here, which being summarized is, "his lordship regrets that in your opinion trade should be in such a depressed state." Now, the words "your opinion" mean it is his lordship's opinion, based on that of the Administrator, that trade is good. And how does he arrive at that? Well, he takes the return of the revenue for the past couple of years and compares that with former years, and it looks well; but then importers and exporters had to pay duties each year whether they lost or not, hoping for the best; but really the past two years have been most disastrous. Four small mercantile houses have been smashed and disappeared; all the other houses have lost heavily, and some are considering about reducing or giving up the trade. The revenue will not increase then. His lordship "will not allow the use of force to stop native wars; counsel and persuasion must be used." Now, as for the latter, even accompanied by presents, the natives only laugh at them, and accept the presents. "As to protection of traders in Gambia River he cannot depart from the policy laid down already. (See Parliamentary Papers.)

"Expedition planned in the interests of Gambia; any disappointment as to its effect not caused by those who planned and conducted it. So Gambia must pay.

"Other parts of your letter are engaging the attention of the Colonial Office." Such was our answer.

Last mail brought me out a copy of the "Report of the Upper Gambia Expedition," better known as the Timbo Expedition, as printed for Parliament. It is got up so as to impress the M.P.'s "that something has been done." I always said it was suddenly conceived, hastily planned, and insufficiently supplied with stores and means of transit. I now find it was hastily and superficially carried out, but that was not the leader's fault, it was "orders." Fancy timing a man to do a journey in an almost unexplored region in Africa to a certain date; a race against time across country. The result has been very little. Space will not permit of more than notice of salient points.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-11-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "A Snubbed Colony—Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Now for the "memorandum" of instructions for the expedition. The objects of the expedition are "Geographical, to learn the value of Upper Gambia as a highway for trade. Political, to visit and give presents to the Kings of Timbo and Falaba, and chiefs along the route." Now, if the value of the Gambia was sought for, why not take light canoes to ascend it, as was recommended here to Dr. Gouldsbury, and not heavy, clumsy boats? But then he had the boats for nothing, and refused canoes, because they had to be purchased. Thus he had to send his boats back from Bady at the outset of his journey, and go entirely by land. The fact that Timbo is Mohammedan, and Falaba pagan, and in a chronic state of war, should have proved to the Colonial Office the mistake it would be to send the one party to the two places; but everything seemed crowded into the one expedition and its cost. The allowance of stores—food—per day to each officer was miserable in amount, as it is most difficult often in the interior to supplement such supplies with food fit for Europeans, purchased from the natives. "Duplicate receipts of all moneys paid, or presents given to natives must be obtained, countersigned by one officer and a native official." The Government seem to throw doubt on the probity of their own officers: 300l. cash in threepenny pieces is sent, and is "packed in three cases of thirty-six lbs. each." Here comes a joke. The cases are sub-divided into tins of twenty-five lbs. each." How can you sub-divide thirty-six lbs. into tins of twenty-five lbs. each? In a letter of February 15, Dr. Gouldsbury complains of the men suffering from sleeping in the heavy dew. Why not have supplied each man with a piece of heavy cotton cloth, six feet long by two and a half wide, and a curtain of light cotton cloth attached to the sides and ends, two and a half feet deep? This would have protected them, and not much increased the loads they carried. The writer has often used a similar protection when travelling in Africa. We next come to the report of the two native messengers sent by Governor Streeten from Sierra Leone to the King of Timbo to announce to him that Dr. Gouldsbury had started from Gambia for Timbo. This report, couched in its quaint language, is of much interest when we consider that the messengers were uneducated natives. We will now turn to Dr. Gouldsbury's "Report of the Upper Gambia Expedition." He mentions Sir S. Rowe's "energy and zeal" in the organization of the expedition in England. I fully respect his Excellency's energy and talents, and he deserves it; but in this case he used them to take the money from Gambia for the political glory of Sierra Leone, because Gambia has a surplus, and Sierra Leone is in debt. Of course, Dr. Gouldsbury had to report that the steamer St. Mary broke down on her way to McCarthy's Island. Breaking down is chronic with her whenever she goes up the river. Dr. Gouldsbury describes how he was humbugged on his arrival at Yarbutenda, by Nally Saynah pretending to him to be King of Cantora country, when he is only head man of the town of Farintoomba. Where were his Excellency's interpreters? They knew who the man was. In 1876 Nally tried the same game with the writer. I let him do it; I even gave him a small present as "King of Cantora." He took a letter the late Captain Cooper, then Administrator of the Gambia, had given me for the king; he promised to get me horses and donkeys and guides to go to Jellacotta next day; he visited me on the mornings of two consecutive days, but horses, donkeys, or guides did not come. I then sent a messenger to King Collie, at Songcoonda, the capital of Cantora, stating what Nally was doing. Collie came down next day. I had Nally brought before him, stated that he had obtained presents and a letter by saying he was King of Cantora. After that Nally had a warm few hours of it, and Collie fined him heavily. Nally threatened to catch me and flog me, so next day I went to his town. He was most civil, and continued so all the time I was in the country. Evidently he "walked into" the Governor this time. There is no town of "Cantora," as the report says; the town is named Songcoonda.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-11-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Failure of two African Exploration Expeditions', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the meeting of the Royal Geographical Society, on Monday, the 4th December, Sir Roderick Murchison said that he regretted to have to announce the failure of two African expeditions, in the success of which the society had a deep and heartfelt interest, but which had both ended in disappointment. The first was the expedition of the Baron Van Derdecken, to explore the interior of Africa, from Zanzibar, where he intended to go up one of the rivers. He fitted out the expedition entirely at his own expense. He, it would be remembered, was the first to settle the point of the existence of a large snowy mountain in Africa, under the Equator. The Baron, he was sorry to say, had lost both his steamers, and when last heard of was nearly dead himself. He had been fighting with the natives; one European and all the natives went down in the small steamer, and the doctor who accompanied the expedition had been ill, but when last heard of was recovering. He was not able to go further into the details of the misfortune. The other failure was that of the expedition of M. Du Chaillu, who had devoted the whole of the little fortune realised by the sale of his book to fit out a little vessel suited for his purpose. When he arrived out he had to wait for instruments, but did not waste his time, since he sent gorillas and plenty of other curiosities to the British Museum. When he reached the interior the small-pox broke out among the natives, and as they considered that he and his party had brought the disease among them, dissensions followed. M. Du Chaillu had encountered great difficulties, but he (the speaker) was not yet well informed as to their nature. However, he had received a telegram from M. Du Chaillu on Saturday, from Falmouth, saying that he had been obliged to fight his way back to the coast, but that he had managed to save his astronomical instruments and observations.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-12-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1865#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRENCH AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Abbé Debaize, in charge of the French Expedition sent to Africa, has written to the Director of the Paris Observatory a most interesting letter, full of curious details, concerning the "Dark Continent," and the various expeditions which are now exploring it. The letter is dated from Kuihara, near Taboza, and was written on the 17th of October. The Abbé Debaize naturally begins with his own expedition, which had so far been successful. He says: "Yesterday the caravan of the French Expedition, with flags flying and music playing, entered Kouikouron, the capital of Unyanyembe. The most sympathetic reception was given to us by the thousands of negroes who gathered round us. The Sultan and the Governor came out to receive us at the entrance to the capital, and conducted us to a vast building, the same as was given to Cameron when he passed here. So far, my journey has been most fortunate, and I am proud to say, for the honour of the Government of the Republic, that the French Expedition promises to be a great success. Of the five hundred men forming my caravan not one has deserted, and I have not lost a single thing. From Zanzibar to the present spot I have not ceased to enjoy perfect health."

The other expeditions do not appear to be so well favoured. The Abbé Debaize alludes to two in particular—namely, the Belgian Expedition and that of the Missionary Fathers of Algeria. As regards the Belgians, he says: "They have experienced troubles of all kinds. At Meromero a revolt broke out in their camp. Two hundred and eighty of their men abandoned them, carrying off with them a quantity of valuable goods. At Mpuapona one of their Zanzibar men was wounded by a native.
[APRIL 1, 1879.]

---

To avenge him, they killed five of the inhabitants. The whole of the country rose, and war was imminent. The English were obliged to interfere to put an end to the affair. On arriving at Crumbo, the remainder of the men of the Belgian caravan deserted; fresh servants had to be found, and at length the Expedition reached Mirambo, but almost ruined. The missionaries from Algeria, who are going to establish stations on Lake Tanganyika and in the Uganda country, have not been more fortunate than the Belgians. They had to pay a ruinous sum for the right to pass through the Ugogo. They were abandoned by their native servants, and, in addition, attacked by a band of brigands, who stole several valuable chests from them. They have now been a month at Kuihara, and will have to equip themselves."', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1879#article-26', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is announced from Berlin that Dr. Emil Riedeck, who is well known in the geographical world for his successful travels, is at present engaged in making the arrangements for an undertaking which promises to be of the greatest importance in the history of the exploration of Africa. The expedition is to be carried into execution by Herr Gottlob Adolf Krause, and the immediate object is described as the investigation of the languages and social state of the inhabitants of the region about the Niger, Benue, and Tsad Lake. Herr Krause intends to follow the Niger from its mouth upwards for a distance of about 300 miles, and then probably to take up his position in some suitable spot, whence he can make a general survey of the surrounding country, decide on his further course of action and await a favourable opportunity for an advance into the interior. The field for exploration will include the east and central territory of the Fulen (Felata Fulbe) and that of the Haussa Musik people. Herr Krause has spent much time in the most unfrequented regions of North Africa, and is therefore well acquainted with the difficulties of such an expedition. He also possesses the rare advantage of an extensive knowledge of African languages, having studied no less than nineteen of the various languages and dialects spoken between Shan and the Upper Senegal. He can also speak the Ful (Fulfulde), Kanuri, and the Haussa languages. It is hoped that the expedition may be rich in results, and especially in information as to the languages and general social condition of this region, which has been regarded as one of the points which offers most difficulty to those who have attempted to introduce civilization into Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1883#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Extension of our West African Colonies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In the course of an interesting article upon "Our Colonies" in a recent issue of the _Times_, we have the following remarks upon the present position and future prospects of that portion of the world with which the readers of the _African Times_ are especially interested:—

The attention which has been drawn to West Africa by the disastrous fate of a part at least of the Crampel expedition has caused so many wild reports to be circulated on the continent with regard to the state of affairs there, and the conditions under which the race for Lake Tchad is being carried on, that an authentic account of what has been done by the Niger Company in its political capacity may be useful. In the first place, it may be frankly said that for the authorities of the Company the race for Lake Tchad does not exist. In so far as the phrase signifies the mere physical act of going to Lake Tchad, there can be no "race," for their territories are geographically so much nearer to the desired point than the territory of any other Power, and the road connecting them with Kouka, the capital of Bornou, and principal towns upon the lake, is so much more open than any route which can at present be conceived through the French Soudan upon the north and west, or the redoubtable district to the east of Adamona upon the south, that their expeditions have an easy walk over. As regards the political race, the Niger Company has good reason to believe that at present there is no prize to be won, and that the part of practical common sense consists, therefore, in not running.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1891#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Particulars have been received of the French expedition up the River Niger, which started on the 2nd April. It was conducted by Captain Gallieni, with two doctors and two lieutenants, and a number of Senegal men. The party started from Bafoulabé, and as far as Kita they were well received, but in the province of Beledougou, the inhabitants of which were at war with the Sultan of Segou, the expedition encountered much opposition. The whole place was in a state of turmoil, and on the 11th May, near the village of Die, a band of about a thousand Barbara natives attacked the party, and a desperate fight took place. It lasted several hours, and at length Captain Gallieni had to abandon his baggage, leaving fourteen men killed, while about eleven were wounded more or less seriously. He was obliged to retrace his steps to Kita, but he decided to proceed on his journey by another route, and according to the latest accounts he was pushing forward with great energy.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1880#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition to the Upper Niger", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Some months ago I wrote the African Times as to some of the plans of the French Government for the occupation, possession, and development of the valley of the Upper Niger and the countries westward of it, as also the Soudan, and the consequent ruinous effects to this colony, that of Sierra Leone, and British home commercial interests. In that letter I said that among other places the French intended to survey and eventually occupy was Farabuna, a town in Bouree, about sixty miles east of the forks of the Gambia river, and close to the gold mines. Well, early in April a French medical official had instructions to start for North-west Africa, and visit the Bambouk, Mandingo, and Bouree countries, the Futa Jallon highlands, and go on to Timbo, as the principal commercial centre for the latter region. Thus you see the French are determined in time to shut us out from the interior, and confine us to the Atlantic seaboard.

The English expedition to Timbo has got there. Dr. Gouldsbury and his men have returned here, but whatever the results have been are only known to the Home Government; but it is remarkable that French newspapers say that had the English expedition attempted to penetrate beyond Timbo they would have been stopped. Does this mean that France claims sovereignty or holds power over all countries east of that town? If so, the sooner we are transferred to France the better for the improvement of trade here.—Your obedient servant,', 'last_edit_date': '1881-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1881#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A French Explorer in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'M. JEAN DYBOWSKI, the African explorer who last November left Bordeaux to go on a mission to the Gaboon territory, is back in Paris. His tramp lay across the swamps between Loango and Libreville, and took three months. Not a gun or bow was discharged at him all that time. A well-furnished medicine chest enabled him to get through his mission without losing anyone whom he took with him. This was more than he was justified in expecting, as the ground was so marshy that they walked for days through muddy water that sometimes reached the waist. It often took them ten hours to push forward as many miles. They had no food but what was tinned, except now and then manioc and thin fowl. As to the water it was sickening, and rank poison when unboiled. Still the country was a splendid one. It grew trees compared to which the oldest beeches in the forest of Compiègne were mere shrubs. The Natives make out of single trunks canoes sixty or seventy feet long and five feet deep. Trees four yards in diameter are not rare. The Gaboon country is of extraordinary fertility. It might not be so unhealthy to persons settled there and able to defend themselves against the climate, as to explorers. Indiarubber will be an article of staple trade. M. Dybowski claims to have come across a race of copper-coloured dwarfs. They were strong, courageous, and intelligent. He says the English are fast extending their trade on the West Coast of Africa and have set up trading stations in the French possessions through which he passed. The French have not so much as a factory there.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1894#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.689, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FRENCH AND ENGLISH NORTH-WEST AFRICAN EXPEDITIONS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is with very great pain we have to give an account of the massacre of Colonel Flatters, and other members of his party, the full details of which we now furnish to our readers. The civilization of the interior of Africa can only be effected by opening up safe and rapid routes of communication with it, and the Expedition of Colonel Flatters was to prepare the way for opening one of such routes. As the Expedition was approved and assisted by the French Government, we do not at all believe that the project will
**55**

be abandoned because of this disaster, but, on the contrary, that renewed effort will be made on such a scale, and with such precautions, as shall frustrate all treacherous designs on the part of the natives. A new proof has been afforded of the difficulty attending exploring expeditions in Central Africa. If weak, they invite attack for purposes of robbery; if comparatively strong, they arouse hostile feelings, and where they cannot be attacked openly, become victims of treachery, as in the Flatters Expedition.

Two very different accounts will be found in our columns of the British Expedition from the Gambia, under the Government of that settlement. The account which we publish as from Bathurst is from a generally most well-informed correspondent. This account, it will be seen, presages something like failure. The other account, dated "Sierra Leone," which we extract from the columns of the _Times_, seeks to convey the impression of success. If, however, as seems to be there indicated, the success is to be for Sierra Leone, we should like to know how the expense can in fairness be charged against the Gambia, where, although there may be a balance of revenue in the chest, every farthing of the money is urgently required for objects essential to the well-being of the colony. There cannot be any justification for subsidizing the great metropolitan colony of Sierra Leone at the expense of poor despised Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1881#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'On the Climate and Diseases of West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'So much has been said and written about the climate of West Africa, and it has been so long the fashion to abuse and condemn it without inquiry, that the medical profession, like the general public, have accepted and endorsed the common report as an established fact. It is therefore important to find such mischievous exaggerations combated by a medical officer, who writes of West Africa, not from hearsay evidence, but from the experience derived during a residence of twenty-three years in the colony of Sierra Leone and settlements of the Gold Coast. We make these remarks by way of introducing to more general notice the papers above noted, because they supply much valuable and novel information, not only regarding the diseases to which Europeans and natives are subject in West Africa, but because they furnish an interesting description of the topography of Sierra Leone and the Gold Coast.

Mr. Clarke is of opinion that the climate of West Africa, if fairly tested, can stand comparison in point of healthfulness with most of our colonies in the East or West Indies, where endemic and epidemic fevers, dysentery, with cholera to boot, prevail quite as frequently and fatally. There are men now in Europe in the enjoyment of fair health who have lived there for periods varying from twenty to twenty-five years. Comparatively, their number is not small, comprehending persons of all classes—governors, civil and military officers, merchants, and missionaries, with their wives and families. He states "that formerly many officers in the English, Dutch, and Danish service resided upon the Gold Coast, some fourteen, twenty, and thirty years,* and enjoyed good health, although those in subordinate positions had to remove from one station to another." The fact ought no longer to be concealed, that half at least of the deaths and incapacities which occur amongst Europeans arise from errors of personal economy, and that the mortality lists are unfairly swelled by ascribing to the climate deaths which have been caused by accident or intemperance.

The following passages may be adduced as proof that the climate is not to blame for everything:—', 'last_edit_date': '1863-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: The appointment of military officers to civil and magisterial roles in West Africa led to ineffective governance, administrative inefficiencies, and corruption, highlighting the detrimental impact of blending military and civil authority in colonial administration.
result: The examination of the claim regarding the appointment of military officers to civil and magisterial roles in West Africa reveals a nuanced perspective when combining insights from the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The General History of Africa provides a broad overview of colonial administration, highlighting the establishment of colonial armies, the manipulation of traditional rulers, and the imposition of European bureaucratic structures, which weakened indigenous governance systems. However, it does not directly address the specific issue of military officers being appointed to civil roles or the resulting inefficiencies and corruption, suggesting that while such blending of authority might have occurred, it is not explicitly documented as a significant issue in the text. In contrast, The African Times articles offer detailed support for the claim, highlighting instances of administrative inefficiencies and corruption due to such appointments. The articles criticize the practice of appointing military officers, like Captain Bravo and Lieutenant Brett, to civil positions such as police magistrates, noting their lack of legal knowledge and involvement in scandalous jobbing and plundering of resources. They also describe the dual roles held by military officers, such as the Inspector-Generalship of Police, as "official plunder" and "shameful robbery," and express concerns about despotic tendencies and a lack of respect for justice, as seen in the cases of Major Bravo and Colonel Mends. While the articles focus more on the moral and ethical implications rather than explicit evidence of administrative inefficiency, they corroborate the claim by illustrating the negative consequences of military involvement in civil administration in colonial West Africa.

gha_sources: [{'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the political field', 'content': "A product of colonialism and one which is often ignored by most historians, but which has turned out to be of crucial and fundamental importance, was, as is evident from R. E. Betts' contribution (Chapter 13), a full-time or standing army. As has been amply demonstrated, most traditional African states south of the Sahara did not have standing armies. In the whole of western Africa, it was only Dahomey that had a standing army with its unique female wing, the famous Amazons. In most cases, there was not a dichotomy between civilians and soldiers. Rather, all adult males, including even members of the ruling aristocracy, became soldiers in times of war and civilians in times of peace. Thus, one of the most novel institutions introduced by each colonial ruler was the professional army. These armies were originally created, most of them in the 1880s and 1890s, first for the conquest and occupation of Africa, then for the maintenance of colonial control, and, finally, for the prosecution of global wars and the suppression of independence movements in Africa. After the overthrow of the colonial rulers, these armies were not disbanded but were taken over by the new independent African rulers and they have turned out to be the most problematic of the products of colonialism since, as W. Gutteridge has admitted, the armed forces have 'operated in the longer term against the stability of the ex-colonies'. '$^{6}$ Indeed, as will be seen in the next volume, as a result of their repeated and often unnecessary and unjustifiable interventions in the politics of independent African states, those armies have become the heaviest of the millstones round the necks of African governments and peoples.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the political field', 'content': "Another important but negative political impact of colonialism was the weakening of the indigenous systems of government. In the first place, as S. Abubakar has recently pointed out and as is evident from many of the chapters above, most of the African states were acquired as a result of the conquest and deposition or exile of the then rulers which 'certainly brought into disrepute the whole business of chieftaincy, especially during the period before the First World War'.$^{13}$ Some of the colonial powers, such as the French as we have seen already, also abolished some of the traditional monarchies and ruling families altogether, appointed people as chiefs who had no right to such posts and turned all of them into admini› strative officers. The British and the Belgians retained the traditional rulers and their institutions and even, as R. F. Betts has shown (Chapter 13), created some where they did not exist and tried to administer the colonies through them. However, the colonial officials on the spot became, in effect, dictators instead of advisers to these traditional rulers and used them also to enforce some of the measures deemed obnoxious by their subjects such as forced labour, direct taxes and compulsory recruitment of men for the colonial armies. This manipulation of the institution of chieftaincy resulted in loss of prestige and respect of the traditional rulers in the eyes of their subjects. The colonial records, as recent research into rural politics in the inter-war years in Ghana has shown,$^{14}$ are full of revolts and rebellions by the young men against their chiefs and even their destoolment. Besides, the colonial system of administering justice in which subjects could appeal to the colonial courts further weakened not only the authority but also the financial resources of the traditional rulers. $^{1 s}$ Furthermore, the spread of the Christian religion undermined the spiritual basis of the authority of the kings. In all these ways, then, the colonial system, in accordance with its own interests, at times weakened or even destroyed the traditional rulers and at times allied with them and used them. But in both cases, the colonial system finally diminished their authority.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The significance of colonialism for Africa', 'content': "Fundamental and destined to be lasting and felt by all members of the society, also, was the impact of colonialism in the political field. As we have already seen, the very physical appearance of the independent states of Africa is the creation of colonialism. With the adoption of the principle of the sanctity of national boundaries by the Organization of African Unity, this appearance is not likely to be altered. Secondly, even though indepen› dence has been regained, there is no doubt that there has been a fundamental and permanent shift in the source of political power and authority. In pre-colonial days, power was exercised by the traditional elite of kings, queens, family, clan and religious heads. But colonial rulers were compelled to restore African independence and sovereignty, as will be seen in the next volume, not to the traditional ruling elite but to the new elite or members of the upper and lower middle classes, the creation of the colonial system, and this situation is never going to be reversed. If anything, the chances of African traditional regal institutions being abolished altogether, as for example they have been in Guinea, are much greater than their retention let alone their rehabilitation. Thirdly, it was colonialism that gave birth to African nationalism which was the product of the sense of anger, resentment, bitterness, frustration and alienation generated by the colonial system. Fourthly, one colonial legacy which again has already played such a decisive role in the politics of post-colonial Africa is the army. This institution is not likely to be abolished and, as will be seen in the next volume, it has already changed the course of the history of many an African country, and it seems as if it has not completed its political innings yet. 'The man on horseback', to borrow Finer's phrase,$^{55}$ is going to be with us for a long time and will serve as a constant reminder, if ever we need one, of the colonial episode. Finally, it appears that the judicial and political institutions - the courts, parliaments, regional and district commissioners, etc. - are going to be retained even though some modifications and adaptations have been and will continue to be made. Probably more than in the economic field, then, the impact of colonialism in the political field was really fundamental and in many respects has proved of lasting con› sequence.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.636, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': 'Colonial rule and structure', 'content': "Throughout sub-Saharan Africa during the inter-war period, the chief became an administrative agent and not a 'native authority' and his traditional roles and powers were greatly weakened or curtailed. This shift in position, even in regions submitted to indirect rule, is easily explained. Most obviously, traditional functions were distended by new demands, such as the collection of taxes, the taking of censuses, or the recruitment of labour and military conscripts. Where there appeared to European eyes no satisfactory individuals in positions of traditional authority, other personnel, such as veterans, non-commissioned officers or clerks, were installed as chiefs. This was especially the case in French and Portuguese colonies where the local roles for the recruitment of personnel for chief› taincy positions were more often than not violated. Then, chiefs were some› times endowed with political significance which had not previously been inherent in their office; on other occasions they were installed in acephalous societies where they previously had no administrative purpose. Examples of these two developments are found among the Igbo of Nigeria, the Gikuyu of Kenya and the Langi of northern Uganda. ! 6", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.052, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Methods and institutions of European domination', 'section_title': 'Colonial rule and structure', 'content': "In theory such indirect administration also applied to French colonial activities south of the Sahara, but in fact practice was at severe variance with it. In a statement frequently referred to as most descriptive of the methods which the French actually pursued in this region between the wars, the Governor-General of French West Africa, Joost Van Vollenhoven, remarked in 1917: The chiefs 'have no power of their own, for there are not two authorities in the cercle ... ; there is only one! Only the commandant du cercle commands; only he is responsible. The native chief is but an instrument, an auxiliary'.$^{14}$ Despite official pronouncements, therefore, the French used indigenous authorities not indirectly, but directly and subordinately in their colonial administration. And in like manner so did the Portuguese.\nLugard's form of indirect rule was initially successful in Northern Nigeria although discredited by some critics as unduly conservative$^{15}$ and was then extended after the war throughout much of British Africa, including the newly acquired German possessions of Tanganyika and the Cameroon. It was even adapted by the Belgians for their use in the Congo after 1920. Although conditions were nowhere else so optimal or the results so successful as in the Hausa-Fulani region of Nigeria, the British did try to follow the contours of local custom so that even newly devised institutions, like local councils, were in consonance with indigenous forms of organization. Though directed against the Levantines (who were accused of creating scarcity by hoarding essential commodities, and of elbowing out local middlemen), these riots were in fact a violent and uncoordinated protest against what were believed to be injustices arising from the manage› ment of the colonial economy. The looting and the riots spread from Free› town to Moyamba, Kangahun (25-26 July 1919), Mano, Boia, Makump, Bo, Bonthe, Mange and Port Lokko. You shall hear from me again by the next mail.'}, {'id': 706, 'article_title': 'Sierra Leone', 'full_section_title': 'Sierra Leone', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1865#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_10_1865', 'content': "The first is the abolition of the practice of the Military Commandant being the Lieutenant-Governor in the absence of the Governor-General. The proposal was made by Governor Hill, and it is evident that he did so in order that his son, who was then in command of the troops, might have a share in the government of the place when he was absent. By having the Military Commandant we are likely to have men who might be entirely unfit for the post, who might know less than nothing about affairs in Western Africa generally, and who might lead to serious complications.

The Senior Lieutenant-Governor on the Coast should, in future, replace the Governor-General; and, prior to his arrival, the Colonial Secretary should assume the office of Acting Governor.

Secondly. There should be a Legislative Assembly, whose members should be composed of men from Bathurst, the Gold Coast, Lagos, and Sierra Leone. Each place should send at least from six to fifteen members.

Thirdly. A Municipal Council should be formed in the colony, a certain standard of education being made compulsory for every one who presents himself to be elected as mayor, alderman, or councillor. It will be injurious if men without education be appointed, since men hostile to the cause of Africa will then have a great deal to say; being uneducated they will not understand the duties and responsibilities of the post, and there will be a great triumph among the anti-African party. It is a predominant fear here amongst the educated young men that, should the Governor and Council not enact stringent and proper rules for the election, the predominance of one tribe will lead to that unhappy result. Self must be forgotten—the benefit of Africa must be the ruling principle. But you will hear from me again.—Yours truly,  
SUNACIRPA.

**LIBERIA.**

Brett* was gazetted Justice of the Peace, and then, in another Official Gazette, we learned he was *Acting Stipendiary Magistrate, vice Mr. Thomas Mayne, resigned under pension, owing to ill health*. Now this is too bad—a piece of scandalous jobbing, and a flagrant plunder of a colony that needs every penny of its resources. This Mr. Mayne, late Stipendiary Magistrate, came out to the Coast as steward in a trading vessel, belonging to Steward and Douglas, of Liverpool. He *left* the ship here at Lagos—took to selling rum in bottles and other small affairs, and afterwards became clerk to Mr. M'Coskry. When the cession of Lagos to Great Britain took place, Mr. M'Coskry, becoming Acting Governor, made Mr. Mayne Stipendiary Magistrate. One would have thought that 400l. a year, with etceteras, was pretty well for Mr. Mayne, considering how he came here, and you may imagine what sort of police magistrate's law we have had from him. But I should not have said anything, and let bygones be bygones, but for this outrage on the community—this robbery of the Lagos revenues—in granting him a pension of some 90l. or 100l. a year. into the hands of any military Tom, Dick, or Harry. We are not a company of soldiers to be kept under military rule, of which, perhaps, Lieut. Cry out for us, Mr. Editor.—Yours obediently,'}, {'id': 1518, 'article_title': 'Civil Appointments to Military Officers', 'full_section_title': 'Civil Appointments to Military Officers', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1869#article-14', 'issue_date': '23_03_1869', 'content': 'We have so often entered the lists against that most injurious system which selects the officers of the West India Regiments in garrison on the West Coast of Africa for civil, and especially magisterial appointments, that it is only natural we should protest anew against it, whenever and wherever it is acted upon. We felt it to be our duty last month to state fully our convictions as to what the public interests of the West Coast demanded, as regards the delegation of power by the Governor-in-Chief on occasions of his temporary absence from the seat of his Government at Sierra Leone; and we think we showed beyond dispute that the delegation of the supreme power to any officer of a corps in garrison on such occasions was not only a public injury and wrong, but was in effect an unjustifiable and dangerous departure from that judicious policy of the Home Government which makes the military power in the colonies and dependencies of Great Britain subservient to the civil power in the person of the Governor-in-Chief; that in all cases of the absence of the latter from the principal seat of his Government, the Colonial Secretary should, by virtue of his office, become Acting Governor-in-Chief; that it is the duty of the Home Government to send out, and that they are supposed to send out to the West Coast, as Colonial Secretaries, persons fit and qualified to hold temporarily such command—and that the Governor-in-Chief, delegating his powers temporarily to such Colonial Secretary, is free from all responsibility as to the mode in which he exercises the trust thus confided in him; while, on the other hand, if the Governor-in-Chief delegate his powers to any officer of the military in garrison he is acting in opposition to the policy of the Home Government, and would be and ought to be held personally responsible for everything done by the said military officer in virtue of the powers thus improperly placed in his hands.
